Those joining the Duchess for the chat include Annie Lennox and former prime minister of Australia Julia Gillard.  Meghan has been described by the s host as a royal not afraid to embrace full-on feminism. Asked how her pregnancy was going, she said: Very well. Its funny, Id actually been joking these past few weeks Id seen this documentary on Netflix about feminism and one of the things they said during pregnancy was I feel the embryonic kicking of feminism. I loved that. So boy or girl, whatever it is, we hope that thats the case.   The group today are talking about the positive opportunities that come when women are given wider access and equal opportunities. Annie Lennox is founder of The Circle, an organisation supporting and empowering womens lives around the world, while Ms Gillard is chairwoman of the Global Institute for Womens Leadership at Kings College London, which is hosting the event. Other members of the  include Adwoa Aboah, who set up the open social discussion  Gurls Talk and Chrisann Jarrett, founder of the equal access to higher education campaign Let Us Learn. Also on the  is Angeline Murimirwa, executive director of the Campaign for Female Education in Africa and co-founder of Cama, a pan-African network of young female leaders. The  is chaired by Anne McElvoy, senior editor of The Economist and columnist with the Evening Standard.   Asked about her own personal journey, Meghan said: “At the age of  I had seen a commercial at the time that I thought to be very sexist. Truth be told, at , I didnt even know what sexism meant. I just knew that something struck me internally that was telling me it was wrong, and I knew that it was wrong. She said she used that as her moral compass, adding: It really set up the trajectory for me to say,there was a wrong,there is a lack of justice, and there is an inequality, then someone needs to do something. And why not me  Once I became old enough to travel, specically to developing countries and see what was happening abroad, I think for me what really resonated was the lack of education for girls, and how that has a ripple effect on so many things, she said today. Meghan added: It really does solve so many of the world’s problems when a girl has access to education. You look at it and you can say, here are the vulnerabilities and the challenges that come about when they don’t have access to education, she continued. Early childhood marriage, susceptibility to trafficking, modern slavery, all of that. But equally look at all the positives that come out of it when you do have access to education for young girls. How it affects the economic development, the GDP. Billions of dollars on the table are lost by girls being pulled out of education.   Meghan spoke about work in India she did a few years ago with a grassroots organisation trying to de-stigmatise menstruation. She said: Giving them access to be able to get these products, but in the same construct having these women mobilised to set up microfinance to sell these pads and other things that are needed to other women in the community. So again it feels like its one issue but it ends up solving so many. Because when you see how many girls are hindered and taken out of school simply because theyre ashamed about going through that transition in le, or because no-one wants to talk to them about it because they dont have what they need and theyre using old rags - literally. Which of course is propelling disease and so many other symptoms that come from this. At the end of the day, we are doing our part just to normalise the conversation. Thats the first step. Because again this is  per cent of the population thats affected by something that can also end up creating the most beautul thing in the world. So its a strange one that its ended up becoming so stigmatised. Remember its also in our own communities that its happening, and the only way we sht that is by talking about it which is why the work you do with Gurls Talk is so important.  Meghan has today become vice-president of the Queens Commonwealth Trust, the organisation has announced. The Duchess has joined her husband Harry, who is president, at the body, while the Queen is its patron. In this new role, the Duchess will highlight the trusts partnerships with young people across the Commonwealth, and in particular its work supporting women and girls, the trust said in a statement. The announcement was made a few hours before the discussion , organised by the Trust, of leading feminists and national figures to mark International Womens Day. Nicola Brentnall, the Trusts chief executive, said: We are particularly delighted that the first opportunity of formally working together with Her Royal Highness comes on International Womens Day. This squares perfectly with our focus on amplying the work and contribution of those furthest away from power. Women across the Commonwealth and the globe often face the biggest impediments to success. So we are delighted to have our vice-presidents support in helping others to overcome those obstacles.  Today Meghan told the  she felt privileged to have her role. She said: And I think, you know, looking at my role, and Im very very privileged to have now with the QCT, just expands that  to be able to go to  Commonwealth countries and do this level of work all across the globe because again, it is about global feminism, it is about a parity and equality for all of us. It started at , but still feels like its just beginning. Meghan has made womens empowerment a key part of her campaigning work and during her recent tour of Morocco with the Duke told a group of female executives and entrepreneurs: Women have to challenge everywhere in the world.

title: mum having sleepless nights feels
story: NewsMum having sleepless nights and feels threatened by ft pole outside homePainter and decorator Sally Grfiths, , from the Wirral, has complained to BT about the pole which she feels is a safety concernShareCommentsByTom Houghton:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video wirral-mum-speaks-out-pole-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum claims she is having sleepless nights and feels threatened by a ft telegraph pole that has been erected outside her window by BT. Sally Grfiths, from the Wirral, is so dismayed by the unsightly object she is considering leaving the home she has lived in for the past  years. The -year-old was horried last week when she woke to discover the new addition outside her front gate - and the mum-of-three is flabbergasted that nobody asked her permission.She told the Liverpool Echo : I cant sleep at night anymore. Its affecting so many parts of my le. Its so tall I feel threatened by it.I feel like its going to fall on me, every time it gets windy, I see the thing shaking - it could snap. I was up at am this morning worried about it.   Ms Grfiths said when men in hi-vis came last Thursday, she assumed they were carrying out gas works. A notice about the pole had been put up on a road sign across the road - but it had the incorrect street name, and caused confusion. She complained to BT after the work had been done, but is yet to hear back. The painter and decorator said: I didnt think anything of it because we had a blackout a couple of weeks ago here, so it could have been the gas. According to Ms Grfiths, there are plenty of other places it could have been safely erected nearby, and that the roads and pavement in the New Brighton area were already narrow enough without further obstructions. Staff and visitors parking to use the nearby health centres mean the road is already congested, and cars are often forced to drive onto the kerb to give way or reverse, she said.   The road cant take it, she added. It will be a problem for wheelchairs and the elderly, and a problem at night time as visibility around here is not good. We just dont know why theyve put it there. People dont know what to do anymore. We are fed up - defeated it shows no respect for the public at all. Im thinking of moving its depressed me that much. Im already starting to hate the area. Id like to be listened to as a resident, and to get that pole removed. Ms Grfiths said she and other residents had been in touch with local ward Councillor Pat Hackett, who has been very helpful.   Cllr Hackett said: [BT] need to ensure they consult more before they install this large piece of street equipment, we know it provides a great service, but it needs to be placed in a position that does not intrude or impinge on residents quality of le by obstructing pedestrians and access to the entrance of this property. At the very least they only had to have a chat by going around and speaking to the local community before they installed it, which would have helped everybody concerned. BT dont require local authority approval to erect telegraph poles. A spokesman for BT Openreach said: “We’re going to take a closer look at this, in light of the concerns raised by people living nearby. Updating or installing new infrastructure can be a challenging and complex task at times, but we always try and carry out our work sensitively and with minimal disruption to the local community.”

title: mum wins landmark case over
story: NewsMum wins landmark case over baffling road sign that made council £k a weekEmma Bartholomews mum was fined at a notoriously baffling no left turn sign that has made a council nearly £millionShareByTalia Shadwell:,  MAR NewsReporter Emma Bartholomew took on Hackney Council over her mums fine and won"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-three has won a landmark case against a council over a fine at a baffling no left turn sign that has made the authority over poundmillion. And Emma Bartholomews triumph could open the floodgates to similar cases over inadequate road sign claims at other spots bringing in cash for councils. When Emmas mum was fined by Hackney Council at the confusing bend, she decided to take on the East London local authority.The Hackney Gazette journalist noted it had made more than pound million in the nine months since the cameras had been installed.  She decided to help her mum appeal the ticket after her mum was stung with a fine while she was on her way to perform an act of generosity. Emmas mum had been dropping off clothing donations to St Josephs Hospice in Mare St for its charity jumble sale when she was snapped, she said. Rather than have her mum pay the pound fine, Emma decided it was time to do something about the notorious fine spot. She said her mum had no idea about the camera. An independent adjudicator ultimately agreed with the mother-daugter duo that the signs at the turn from Mare St into Richmond Rd were inadequate.  But Emmas mum risked being slapped with an even bigger fine by taking the council on after it initially rejected their request to overturn the fine. By appealing the pound discount charge, Emmas mum faced it growing to poundshe lost the case. But the tribunal agreed with the pair and overturned Emmas mums fine. Sean Stanton-Dunne of London Tribunals told the Gazette he had come across the case at least five times. He said each time “sent a clear message” to the council the signs in Mare Street were “inadequate.”Allowing the appeal, Mr Stanton-Dunne said: “The no left turn sign is positioned beyond the traffic lights so that it may not be clearly seen before the lights.   The lights are in front of the sign and so risk causing an obstructed view from car level in the left hand lane. “There is an advance warning sign further back from the lights but this is tilted at an angle so that it does not directly face the approaching motorist.” However he does not have the power to force changes. The signs are supposed to warn vehicles they can can no longer turn left into Richmond Road between am and am, and pm and pm, from Monday to Saturday. The change was made last June due to the street outside London Fields Primary School being made a school street in an effort to reduce air pollution. But the stretch has subsequently become a cash cow the local council.   Figures revealed by the Gazette showed Hackney Council was raking in pound, a day from the spot, with almost , people hit by penalty charge noticessince its installation. Just  people, or  per cent of all those issued with a PCN, appealed to the independent adjudicator, where a third won. Just , of the the , notices motorists have tried to appeal in the last nine months have been cancelled. But the council reportedly did not agree with the ruling, with a spokesman telling the Gazette they believe the Department of Transport-approved signs go over and above the requirements for a restriction of this type. A spokesperson added: “Nonetheless we always remain open to making further improvements, and will be inviting an adjudicator to visit Richmond Road so that we can discuss any concerns they may have, and agree how to address them for the benefit of motorists.” But the reporter who took on the council doesnt think her battle ends here. She has pointed out the local authority says the sign adheres to DoT guidelines. She told the Mirror she has no answers yet on whether they will change the signs to make it less confusing. Obviously I think they should, but there doesnt seem to be any authority who can make them do that. Theyve changed the signs once already after some people got hit with more than  tickets when it was first introduced. They obviously havent yet done enough to make the sign visible enough - and the adjudicator agreed with me. Emma pointed outthe scheme is supposed to be for the benefit of the local school:I do wonder why its still in force on a Saturday from am to am and pm to pm, when the school is closed. It does seem to indicate that theyre happy with the situation as it is and the phenomenal amount of money the sign is racking up.

story: AdvertorialHow British firms could be losing millions by getting sucked into the tech raceYorkshire Banks Group Business Banking Director gives his verdict on the biggest technology questions for small businesses in ShareByDave Masters:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Advertorial"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTechnology is vital for all businesses up and down the country. It can revolutionise how a company works in so many areas, from more efficient front line production to improved data analysis. But with technological advances moving at a faster rate than human skills, it is vital for small and medium sized businesses to keep up. So to help, Yorkshire Bank’s Group Business Banking Director, Gavin Opperman, is here to answer your questions... Q How can small businesses reduce costs associated with new technology  A Every small business needs technology to support them to make their business more efficient. Technology is moving faster than human skills are, which is why it is necessary for small businesses to weigh up exactly what piece of technology they want to own, its longevity and whether its development can be outsourced. Q Is understanding the latest technology essential for all small businesses  A Most small businesses will need to adopt some level of technology to make their business run efficiently. However,small businesses get caught up in the technology race too much they can move away from their core business. Remember to find a balance between what is needed and how to make the businessoptimally. Q What technology should small businesses be looking out for  A Every small business is dferent. There’s a number of exhibitions that they can attend to see what technology is most suited to them. Small businesses should look for options that will give them long-term sustainability at an economical rate and ultimately make their business more efficient. Q Many small businesses are struggling with the complexity of new technology – how can they simply the concept  A At Yorkshire Bank, we strive to bring industry experts and like-minded people together. Many of the sectors or businesses are prepared to share their knowledge to others in the industry. It is about finding the right technology to fit your business, and one that is suitable over a long period. Q How can small businesses keep up to date with the latest products and services available  A When it comes to technology, Yorkshire Bank provides a relationship model. We as bankers aren’t there as technology experts, but what we can do is share best practice. We can introduce small businesses to experts in our portfolio who can advise on the latest products and services available. Q Many small businesses are hindered by time and internal resources – how can they still embrace new technology  A The biggest challenge Yorkshire Bank has identied with small businesses is the skills shortage, which puts pressure on internal resources. A lot of universities are developing skills in technology, but it’s how small businesses can retain the talent within that. The aim would be to keep the intellectual property within  the region, so small businesses can embrace new technology without added time or training.Find out more about a business bank that works for you at YBonline business

If it does go, obviously there could be tragic circumstances. A little bit went down at the back end of yesterday. Little bits go all the time. The holiday caravans nearest to the new rupture in the Eastfield area of the site will have to be relocated, which takes the total number of relocations up to  so far this year. He said: The last couple of months has been the worst period of erosion in recent years. Certainly a talking point has been the hot summer of last year thats dried out all the clay.   East Riding councillor Barbara Jefferson has raised the issue with the council and has been told officials visited the site recently to look at erosion and discuss health and safety issues. A council spokesman says: “While the existing coastal defences in Hornsea protect part of the Longbeach site from erosion, to the south of these defences, the coast is eroding at a rate of approximately . metres a year, with a maximum inidual loss of . metres. “Over time, this erosion, which is monitored regularly, has resulted in the need to relocate or remove caravan pitches from the site.” The council has been working with landowners in the affected area to ensure the risks to people are minimised. story: NewsTeens bragged they were on the run for murder after beating angler to deathScott Wilkinson suffered fatal brain injuries after being attacked by two teenagers and their cousins in SurreyShareByBen CusackTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsScott Wilkinson, , was killed by three members of the same family during a summer fishing trip in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA group of teens bragged to their friends that they were on the run for murder after beating a fisherman to death in Surrey. Scott Wilkinson, , was battered to death with a plank of wood by brothers Lenny and Shane Crawt, aged  and  at the time, and their then -year-old cousin Charlie Smith. The Crawt brothers, now  and , were found guilty of murder and Smith, , was found guilty of manslaughter at Guildford Crown Court on March . The -year-old was murdered during a nighttime fishing expedition on Donkey Island, near his home in Walton-on-Thames, Surrey, in July, .   He suffered fatal brain injuries when the three young men brutally assaulted him with a piece of wood. The jury heard how the Crawt brothers and their cousin Smith had been camping on the island. They fled to nearby Grovelands Park after the incident and met a gang of youths they knew. According to Surrey Police, one of the three said: I wouldnt say anythingI was you because we killed someone tonight. Smith told an old school friend that he was on the run for murder.   Detective Inspector Paddy Mayers, who led the investigation, said: This was a vicious and senseless attack on Scott Wilkinson who after the attack was left alone to die. His injuries were so serious that they were not survivable. Shane Crawt, Lenny Crawt and Charlie Smith thought they had got away with it and even boasted about what they had done. They then denied their involvement before blaming each other, putting Scotts family through a distressing trial where they had to listen to graphic detail to what Scott had gone through.   DI Mayers said the trio had never shown any remorse for what they have done. After the verdict, Scotts family shared a heart-wrenching tribute. They said: We have such fond memories of Scott which include him misbehaving with his brother Shaun when they were children much to the consternation of his mother Janet and humorous delight of his father David. Fishing was a family hobby which brought us all together. It created shared experiences during long summer holidays, adventurous trips to Ireland with long drawn out tales of the one that got away. The energy and enthusiasm which Scott directed towards fishing was reflective of his character towards people. He offered friendship, kindness and closeness to those that wanted or needed it. He enriched the lives of the people who knew him. Shane Crawt, from Purley, Lenny, from West Molesey, and Charlie Smith, of no fixed abode will be sentenced at the same court at a later date.

story: NewsTwo thirds of UK homes have been stained by kids - and its not just pasta sauceDont look too closely at the carpets - Youll find all sorts.ShareCommentsByAlice Hughes:,  MAR NewsThe latest kids craze - slime - is one of a whole host of items ruining British floors "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo thirds of Brit families have had their flooring seriously damaged or stained - by clumsy kids, a study found. A poll revealed the extent to which children can innocently damage a home, with the likes of pasta sauce, blackcurrant squash and even the latest craze – slime – all leaving their mark. The most common stage for kids to cause havoc was revealed to be between new-born and three, with some parents admitting the contents of their child’s nappy was the cause of some of their floor stains. Children’s drinks were found to be the biggest culprit of the damaged flooring followed by craft materials such as ink and paint.  But three in  of the parents polled also said liquids are the worst thing for children to spill, with cosmetics and food not far behind. Carine Jessamine of Selco Builders Warehouse, which conducted the research, said: “The research shows parents everywhere have to deal with serious spillages.   “Everyone accepts children are going to have incidents when they are growing up, but when the repair bill can drt into the thousands it can prove costly for parents”. It also emerged one in five parents have had to pay up to pound to get their flooring repaired or professionally cleaned, while one parent even said they faced a bill of pound, to repair the damages. The worst flooring for stains and damages was revealed as carpet. And the most common room in the house for flooring to be ruined is in the bedroom with  per cent of spillages happening there. This is closely followed by the dining room and kitchen, showing how food, including peanut butter and beetroot according to respondents, is such as big issue.   Interestingly, the results of the study carried out among  Brits showed young girls are just as likely to leave behind a trail of destruction as boys. Carine added: “Carpets are clearly the worst type of flooring for damage and stains from a child’s activities. “The general perception is that one of the big benefits of having laminate flooring in your home is that it is more resistant to spillages and stains and that theory is certainly backed up by this research. “We’re also seeing increasing demand for new generation Luxury Vinyl Flooring which is so hard-wearing it comes with a -year warranty perfectyou have young kids!” Read more stories of childhood destruction here, including a wine tsunami and why you should probably cry over spilt milk here: https:www.selcobw info kids-damage-flooring

title: inside remains stunning 19th century
story: NewsInside remains of stunning th century house where gold is buriedRockwell house in Milledgeville, Georgia, was built for Colonel Samuel Rockwell in  and he is said to have suffered a heart attack at finding out the cost of the cast iron fenceShareCommentsByMark McConville:,  MAR NewsRockwell House "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRemains of a th century house where gold is rumoured to be buried have been revealed in stunning images. Rockwell house in Milledgeville, Georgia, comprises of eight rooms with a spiral staircase, slave quarters and a carriage house at the rear. The original owner is said to have had a heart attack after learning his fence cost more than the house, according to urban explorer known as Abandoned Southeast who took the photos. The house, which was a labour of love, features a grand entrance with steps leading to an intricate porch and pillars, and the cast iron fence said to have provoked the heart attack.   Other incredible images show the spacious interior with most of the rooms cleared out, while ornate woodwork remains above the doors and fireplace with two lonely seats being all thats left. This magnicent home was built for Colonel Samuel Rockwell in  in Milledgeville, Georgia, said Abandoned Southeast. The Rockwell House was built by architect Joseph Lane Sr, who Rockwell brought with him from Maine. Lane also designed buildings at nearby Oglethorpe University. He added: A cast iron fence in front of the extensive lawn is reported to have cost , when it was new while the house only cost ,.   The story is told that when Col Rockwell learned of the cost of the fence, he had a heart attack. There are no markings on the fence as to where it came from. One source said the fence came from London, England. Many historians believe the fence to have been cast in Milledgeville. It has been attributed to the Dugal Fern and Brothers Foundry. He continued: There are a number of stories and rumours about the Rockwell House including a rumor of gold buried in the vicinity of the house.  Col Rockwell was the seventh generation of Rockwells in America. He was born in  in Albany, New York. Rockwell moved from Maine to Georgia in . He was a slave holder and a member of the Georgia Militia. Prior to his law practice in Milledgeville, he served as an attorney in Savannah. Rockwell House was occupied by Col Rockwell and his family for only a very short period due to his death in . It is not knownthe house was left vacant, but eventually the property was owned by Hershel V Johnson.  Strangest things in UK museums - and why you might not be able to see them for longIn , Johnson became Governor and used the residence as his summer home. In the following years, Rockwell House was home to numerous merchants and farmers. Mr Marshall Bland purchased the house in  and lived there a decade. The Blands moved out for a year in  when Mr Bland believed he sold the house. A man from out of state wanted to buy the house and paid Mr Bland a deposit. The man never ed to take possession of the house and the family moved back into the house in . The house was sold by Mr Bland to his cousin, Oscar Ennis, who occupied the home with his family until .   The house was sold to Dr Robert Watson in . Dr Watson began work to restore the home until tragedy struck. In August , while removing paint with a blow torch, workers set fire to an upstairs portion of the house. The house was stripped of a lot of its original features after this fire. A renovation has been underway since  to restore the Rockwell House. This year it was purchased by Ross Sheppard, a realtor in Atlanta who specialises in historic preservation.

The image, taken in January , sparked an investigation by the Discovery Channels team of investigators. After first looking into the possibility it was a crater made by the German bombings of Belfast in World War Two, the team realised the circular area was actually raised. Investigator Sheila Hoffman said the mound had hard edges so was unlikely to be the result of an explosion or depression in the ground from bombs, but appeared to be a mound.   Archaeologist Dr Karen Bellinger agreed and found there were large stones visible, making the site most likely to have been a Stone Age henge monument, and that is was likely used by Celtic Pagan savages. Speaking in the Discovery Channel documentary, Dr Mark Altaweel said Celtic tribes were in constant conflict with each other. And typically before battle they would have their priest perform ceremonies to get the tribe ready for the conflict ahead.   He speculated that before battle, humans including young men and girls were killed here to pacy and please pagan gods. He said: Typically the Celts captured someone to sacrice them. They would perform these rituals on these mounds, places that were elevated, in a way to bring them closer to their gods.

story: NewsWoman shocked by friends incredibly cruel comment after her miscarriageA young woman was left feeling hurt after confiding some personal news in one of her work palsShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR NewsWoman couldnt believe what her pal said to her"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen you find out someone close to you has suffered something traumatic, it can be dficult to find the right words to say. title: look angel points secret codes
story: NewsLook where the angel points: Secret codes, the Vatican and a missing schoolgirlEmanuela Orlandi, , disappeared  years ago and now the Vatican is considering opening an unmarked tomb to seeher body is insideShareByMatt Roper:,  MAR NewsEmanuela vanished in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s a tale of murder, secret codes and conspiracy - and even Opus Dei - that could have come straight from the pages of a Dan Brown novel. The fate of Emanuela Orlandi, a -year-old girl who disappeared without a trace from the Vatican on the way to a flute lesson in , has gripped Italians for the last three decades. But now the mystery could finally unravel - with a coded message which appears to indicate where the teenager’s body was secretly buried. “Look where the angel points,” reads the message in an anonymous letter sent to her family. The angel is a centuries-old stone statue on top of an unmarked tomb within the the Teutonic Cemetery, which lies within the Vatican walls.   And unlike other many similar statues in the tiny city state, the angel’s hand is pointing downwards - towards whatever is buried underneath. The cemetery is not accessible to the general public and no-one knows who was once buried there.Yet the tomb is mysteriously tended every day, with a lit red votive candle that is never allowed to go out, and always fresh flowers in a vase. The only thing engraved on it is a marble scroll the angel holds, which reads Requiescat in Pace - or Rest in Peace. The Orlandi family now wants the Pope to grant permission to exhume whoever or whatever lies inside the tomb, which is reported to have been opened “at least once” - and resealed - within the last few decades.   A Vatican spokesman this week said in a statement that the Holy See is “studying” the matter and will soon decide whether to honour the request. If Emanuela is found to have been murdered and buried inside the Vatican it could engulf the Catholic church in its biggest scandal to date. And it will give oxygen to one of the most sensational theories about her disappearance - that the schoolgirl was kidnapped by high-ranking clerics who kept her as a sex slave before killing her. Pierto Orlandi, Emanuela’s brother, said he believes the Vatican’s highest powers know much more about his sister’s disappearance than they have so far let on. “I wish so much that this story was a hoax. I really wish Emanuela was not here,” he told a local newspaper. While this is the most precise indication yet of where she might be buried, the claim that she was snatched by a Vatican paedophile ring has been made before - by people close to the Churchs very centre of power.  The Vaticans chief exorcist Father Gabriele Amorth, a great confidant of retired Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI, said in  that Emanuela was snatched from the streets of central Rome in the summer of  and forced to take part in sex parties.Fr Amorth, who died in , said: This was a crime with a sexual motive. Parties were organised, with a Vatican gendarme acting as the recruiter of the girls. The network involved diplomatic personnel from a foreign embassy to the Holy See. I believe Emanuela ended up a victim of this circle.”In , Monsignor Simeone Duca, an archivist with the Vatican, backed up the exorcist’s claims.He cited “credible information” that “certain factions” inside the Vatican’s diplomatic corps were involved in procuring young adolescent girls for sexual slavery. He, too, said he believed that the teenager was abducted for that purpose and later murdered. It is not the only theory that has emerged about what happened to Emanuela in what is still one of Italy’s most enduring mysteries.  They include the early claim that Turkish militants tied to the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II had taken the schoolgirl to secure the release of Mehmet Ali Agca, who tried to shoot the pope in . Then, in , the mistress of a gangster named Enrico De Pedis told authorities that he organised Emanuelas kidnapping at the behest of the controversial American archbishop, Paul C. Marcinkus, the former president of the Vatican Bank, who died in . Some have suggested that Emanuelas father Ercole, a Vatican clerk, had evidence of wrongdoing committed by Marcinkus, and that he asked De Pedis to kidnap the girl to keep the clerk quiet. A traffic warden who had seen Emanuela speaking to a man in a green BMW the night she disappeared worked to produce a sketch of the man, who looked very similar to De Pedis. And in , Italian journalist Emiliano Fittipaldi published a document that had been stolen from the Vatican. It appears to show that the church knew where the teen was and had been paying her expenses for years, including room and board and gynaecological examinations.  The Vatican called the document  and ridiculous. What is without doubt, though, are the very strange circumstances which surrounded her sudden vanishing on June , . The teenager, who had just finished her second year of high school, left the left the familys apartment in Vatican City and travelled to a flute lesson in Rome. On the way to the flute lesson, the man in the green BMW stopped her on the street and offered her money to sell Avon cosmetics, which she refused. Troubled, she called her sister to tell her about the incident. Once she arrived at the lesson, she was distracted and asked to leave early, around .pm. Emanuela was last seen in front of SantApollinare, a church in Rome belonging to the ultra-secretive Catholic organisation Opus Dei that played a mayor role in The Da Vinci Code novel. In the days after her disappearance the Orlandi family started receiving anonymous calls with tips about their daughters whereabouts, none of them leading anywhere.  Pope John Paul II waded into the case on July , , when he made a public appeal for her safeafter a public prayer, saying I am close to the Orlandi family. Two days after the pope’s address, someone called both the Orlandi family and the Vatican, saying that a group had taken the teen to secure the release of Mehmet Ali Agca. The caller, who was American, backed up his claims by leading agents to a photocopy of Emanuelas registration card for her music school, and sending a letter containing photo copies of the sheet music she was studying at the time. But he stopped communicating after October  and was never heard from again. A number of attempts have also been made recently to locate Emanuela’s remains, with the first linked to the secretive Opus Dei church. The only person ever investigated over the disappearance was Monsignor Piero Vergari, the former rector of the Sant’Apollinare church where she went missing. He was a friend of gangster Enrico De Pedis, and after he died he petitioned to let his body be buried at the Basilica of SantApollinare, a place usually reserved for senior clerics, not criminals.  In , De Pediss grave was exhumed to see whether Emanuelas remains might be hidden inside with his, but although, bizarrely, there were lots of human bones around his tomb, nothing matched the missing teen. And last November, workers renovating an annex of the Vaticans embassy to Italy in Rome discovered bones underneath the flooring, sparking immediate questions they may be connected to the teenager’s disappearance. Sometime after Emanuela’s disappearance, Monsignor Vergari is reported to have worked at the embassy. But the bones turned out to be around  years old. This week’s new lead could yet be another blind alley, or could maybe finally solve the mystery that has obsessed Italy, and haunted the Orlandi family, for over three decades. Emanuela’s brother Pierto knows there is still a long way to go to find the truth, especially as it could take weeks, months or even years, for the Vatican to respond to his family’s request to open the tomb. And with each day that goes by, he is more convinced that the Church knows much more about what happened to his lost sister than they had ever been willing to admit. He said: “Weve been asking for collaboration from the Vatican for  years. “Collaboration that has never been. This time we are asking again. Even collaboration that is discreet, just to understand. Just to remove this doubt.”

title: mum blasted leaving five year
story: NewsMum blasted for leaving five-year-old home alone to cook - and wanting sympathyThe heavily pregnant mum popped out to get a lunch she was cravingShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe little lad was left to fend for himself "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNo one would argue that having young kids is full on.That hateful mummy brain phrase  It exists because parents are often run ragged just trying to keep everything afloat.But does that justy leaving a five-year-old home alone, evenfor an hour  Evenyou believe he can fend for himself  One mum seems to think so, and its caused a huge backlash.The mum, who is also  weeks pregnant turned to Facebook for sympathy, writing in a group: Its a pain being pregnant and having to get my son ready and in the car, so I usually leave him home behind my fianceacutes back .  Well today I got caught. Since Im pregnant I was craving this specic place in the mall. My sons lunch was in the oven and figured by the time it was ready I would be home. My son is potty trained and just plays games on his iPad watches TV. Half an hour after popping out to satisfy her lunch craving, the mum received furious text messages from her fianceacute, who had come back to find his son completely home alone. As for her reaction, she added: I feel degraded and belittled over nothing. A  year-old is perfectly capable of fending for himself for an hour.   Im honestly about to pack my bags and never let my son see his father again...Id rather be a single mother than be spoken to this way. Of course, asking for no judgement did nothing to stop a flood of it coming her way. I mean I might argue a kid can handle themselves for a bit, but a whole hour, with the oven running, no food ready, while she is out at a mall  read one of the more generous responses. She knowingly left her young five-year-old kid at home alone unsupervised with the oven on. Thats insanity, fumed another - and again, thats one of the kinder response. Having asked Reddit how theyd feel in her shoes about her fianceacute, one person added savagely: Its the grim realisation that he fathered a child with a moronic drama queen setting in.

title: council set to allow coffee shops and nurseries to move into successful dundee technology park
story: The council has unveiled plans to boost Technology Park by allowing a wider range of businesses to use the site.And development chiefs have hailed the “success” of the park, which is more than three-quarters full.Council chiefs hope to welcome in a wider range of businesses in the Tech Park – so long as they compliment its existing offering.The park already hosts an Oranges and Lemons nursery, which is popular with parents who work on the estate – and businesses such as that, or an on-site coffee shop, are likely to be welcomed.However, the council has warned that businesses that any such bids will have to “serve employees based in the Technology Park rather than draw further traffic into this employment area”.Gregor Hamilton, head of planning and economic development, will make a pitch to councillors next week to lt planning restrictions currently in place.Together with city development boss Robin Presswood, Mr Hamilton is hatching plans to take back derelict buildings from owners and work with business chiefs to promote the Tech Park anew.He will tell members on Monday current rules permitting only offices and manufacturing facilities “narrowly restrict” the potential role it has to play in Dundee’s economic growth.Mr Hamilton will say: “It is clear the Dundee Technology Park has been a success and signicantly contributes to key employment sectors within Dundee.“Through improved joint working with key stakeholders, the park can be positively promoted with the support of Dundee City Council to build up the unique business park setting.”A number of key buildings, including a graffiti-covered block that looks on to Riverside Avenue, remain vacant and are falling into disrepair.Two of the park’s empty units hold almost % of the total empty space available at the park.One proposal from Mr Hamilton is that the council could apply for a compulsory purchase or sale order to seize unsightly buildingsowners refuse to take action.West End Labour councillor Richard McCready said he was glad to see action being taken.“We need to make sure Tech Park is fit for the st Century and promote jobs by working together with owners, Scottish Enterprise and anyone with Dundee’s best interests at heart.“The park has to play as much of a role as it can and it can do better than it has been. I hope this report is not a one-off, and we keep monitoring it to make sure it remains an important source of jobs.”Alison Henderson, CEO of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said: “Tech Park is a gateway to the city for those coming in from Perth or who come along Riverside – as a first impression it can be mixed.”

title: dundee drink driver 22 told cops she didnt have her keys while hiding them in her underwear
story: A banned motorist who denied drink-driving despite having the car keys in her pants has avoided a jail term.Caitlin McDonald, , was also found with cocaine while out in the city centre last month.Dundee Sherf Court heard she tried to flee from police before lying to them, telling officers she didn’t have the keys to her car.Police conducted a search after tracking her down and finding them in her underwear. The offence came almost a year after McDonald was disqualied from driving for  months.Police became aware of security guard McDonald driving in the city centre in the early hours of February .After spotting the officers, McDonald was seen to reverse her car “at speed” into a car park on St Andrews Street.Depute fiscal Lora Apostolova said: “Officers saw her abandon the car and run off into the car park.“Later that same night, the same police officers traced her. She was asked to release the keys and she said she did not have them.”The keys were later recovered from McDonald while she was at police headquarters on West Bell Street.McDonald, of Wolseley Street, pleaded guilty to driving while disqualied, testing  mics of alcohol in ml of breath, exceeding the limit of  mics, attempting to pervert the course of justice and possessing a Class A drug, namely cocaine.Sherf Lorna Drummond said: “It seems to me quite obvious custody would be warranted.“You are obviously a danger to the public and yourself when you are driving.”Instead of jail, McDonald was ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work, was placed on a restriction of liberty order for  weeks, keeping her indoors between pm-am, and given  months’ supervision.She was also disqualied from driving for  months.

title: dundee gaffer mcintyre delighted at signing winger josh todd
story: Dundee manager Jim McIntyre is “delighted” to have secured the pre-contract signing of winger Josh Todd.The -year-old has impressed at Queen of the South over the past year and the Dens Park boss says he’s been a fan of the former St Mirren man for a while.The Tele revealed back in January the Dark Blues were making a move for the Englishman to bring him in at the end of his contract after he shone for the Doonhamers in their - Scottish Cup draw at Dens Park.Todd set up the opening goal for Stephen Dobbie and was a constant menace to the home defence – something Jim is hoping to see from the midfielder in his side next season.He said: “Josh Todd is a player I have liked for a while.“I went to watch him a couple of times before we played them and he did exceptionally well and then did really well in the game here at Dens.“I’m delighted we managed to do that so I’m looking forward to seeing him in the summer.“He’s not a traditional winger that’ll hit the byline but he makes great runs beyond the strikers and he’s got a goal in him.“He’s an athlete, he can get up and down the pitch, has really good conditioning and knows where the goal is.“He’s also quick. You can’t have enough players with pace.“He’s played No  as well and he fits the bill in terms of the type of player we want to bring to the club.”Despite the club’s immediate future unclear as they battle relegation from the Premiership, that’s not stopped Jim putting preparations in place.In the immediate future, however, is Hearts on Saturday at Dens Park.Jim was at Firhill on Monday night to watch the Jambos draw - with Partick in the Scottish Cup and is hopeful his side can repeat their - success at Tynecastle last month.He added: “We had a really good result against them last time.“They’ve had a wee sticky period with injuries but we know we’ll have to defend better than we have because we will be tested.“I always feel we have a chance of winning games, especiallywe can get our strikers fit and, with the wide players we have, I feel we are always going to create.”

title: dundee owners make fresh bid to supporters society to increase shares
story: Dundee FC’s owners have made a fresh bid to boost their control in the club to over %.The Tele revealed in January that Football Partners Scotland , the majority shareholder owned by Tim Keyes, had made a move to buy the ‘A’ Ordinary shares owned by the Dundee Football Club Supporters Society.With those came rights of veto regarding a range of issues including a stadium share or potential merger with another club.That was knocked back by the Society and now Dundee finance director David Gray has written to them in an attempt to buy their Ordinary shares to bring FPS’ holding to .%.This would allow them to claim Group Tax Relief to offset losses made by the club. A deadline of March  has been made by the club for the Society to decide on two proposals put forward by Dundee FC.The first would see FPS buy the Ordinary shares for £,, the club’s preferred option. These shares have a nominal value, at  pence per share, of £,.The second is for DFCSS to “agree to support resolutions which increase the club’s share capital and then allot shares specically to FPS”.Currently there is no provision in the Society’s rules to sell shares and an extraordinary general meeting would be needed to change that, and with it a vote by its members.The Financial Conduct Authority would also need to be contacted, a process which could take months.DFCSS already had a board meeting scheduled for next Tuesday and will discuss the proposals and their response as a board as well as with their members, despite the sharp time constraint.In a statement, the club added: “At a time when our primary focus is on retaining our Premiership status, we would prefer not to have to undertake an unnecessary time consuming and expensive full share issue and we hope that the Society will support us in agreeing to one of the suggested options.”

title: embrace title race pressure urges dundee uniteds reynolds
story: Mark Reynolds says the pressure is only going to increase on Dundee United as the season nears its end but he’s backed the Tangerines to embrace it by running down leaders Ross County.The Staggies have a five-point advantage on Reynolds  Co. going into United’s final  matches of the campaign and the on-loan Aberdeen man expects the intensity to increase game by game in the race to promotion.He said: “You need to embrace the pressure.“If you are in a team that’s got aspirations to go up and compete in the Premiership you need to deal with pressure.“There are players that don’t deal with that but they don’t play in big teams.“We have a good enough dressing-room and boys who want it and are used to playing under pressure in big games.“Everyone has the capability of thriving in it and that’s what we need to do.“We just need to keep on winning. Ross County will just keep doing what they do but the good thing is we play them twice so it can still be in our hands.“If we beat them in those games then it starts to put the pressure on but we still need them to slip up to make up the eight points.“We’ve left ourselves a lot to do but all we can do is win the games in front of us.“Regardless of who it is, every game will be huge and three points will be massive.”After the disappointment of losing Sunday’s Scottish Cup quarter-final against Inverness, United are targeting an immediateto their recent good league form with  points picked up from their last  available.They take on bottom side Partick Thistle this weekend at Firhill and Reynolds has urged the Terrors to “step up” and grab the three points.He added: “It was disappointing on Sunday and the boys were hurting – it’s right we feel that disappointment and let it sink in before getting back to training yesterday and then focus on the league.“We realise that was a chance to get in a semi-final but the next  games will be like cup finals.“There will be pressure, teams will try to stop us, they’ll make it horrible and we’ll be a scalp.“Teams will want to take points off us but we need to deal with that, step up and find ways to beat them.“If we keep winning then the pressure will increase and increase and it’ll get harder and harder but we need to deal with that.“We need to step up and,we do that, then we’ll have a good chance.”After a testing double header against Inverness Caley Thistle last week with a league win followed by that cup defeat, Reynolds expects the Highlanders to be a handful for their semi-final opponents – whether it’s this weekend’s opponents Partick or Premiership Hearts.He said: “Inverness are a big physical team – they put the ball up the park and play off the back of it and they have good players in amongst that.“Last Tuesday I thought we stood up to that and we won more balls, picked up more seconds and did enough to keep them out.“We didn’t do that on Sunday, we were second to too many balls.“Inverness can do that to teams. They will cause problems.”Reynolds, meanwhile, is happy to see no astroturf surfaces on the horizon after missing recent away trips to Queen of the South and Falkirk on physio’s orders.“That’s the last game on plastic pitches so, unless we go to the play-offs and have to play on one it’ll be fine.“It was just too early, that’s me not long back from a cruciate ligament injury so the advice from the physios was not to play on it and not risk it.“They were the guys that got me back so it would be daft not to listen to them.”

title: former dundee united defender harry souttar called into australian squad
story: Former Dundee United defender Harry Souttar has been called into the Australia U  squad.The -year-old, who is on loan at Fleetwood Town from current employers Stoke City, has accepted a call-up for Australia’s Olympic qualication squad for their training camp in Malaysia and qualiers in Cambodia.Souttar has already represented Scotland at U  and U  level and, along with brother John, is poised to be the first Scottish siblings to play for dferent countries.John made his international debut last year after Hearts boss Craig Levein warned Scotland risked losing him to Australia because he was eligible to play for the Socceroos.Harry had previously insisted it was his dream to play for Scotland.He#s eligible to play for Australia through his mother, who was born in Australia.He stressed two years ago during Scotland U ’s Elite Round qualiers in Czech Republic he was desperate to play for his country.He said: “My ambition has always been to play for Scotland. Who knows, maybe one day I will partner John at the centre of defence for Scotland.“My aim is to try to get myself established in English football and then see what happens.”But Socceroos boss Graham Arnold, who is also in charge of the U  side, insists he’s delighted to have persuaded the former Tangerines and Ross County stopper to follow in the footsteps of Hibs winger Martin Boyle and pledge their future for Australia.The Aussies were alerted to Souttar’s availability by his Stoke City team-mate Adam Federici.Arnold said: “When you look at Harry and his size, he is a beast. However, he is also very good on the ground, too, with his feet and we will take a good look at him.”

title: if they werent there already it is must win time for dark blues
story: Before I start, let me open my big book of cliches and get some of them out of the way.First off the bat, in defence of this piece, cliches are only cliches because they are, generally, true.And it is true that Dundee are about to enter a period of games, some of which are must-win, and most of which are must-not-lose, which could define their season.Before the Dark Blues enter into the post-split realm of six-pointers, though, they must navigate five more tough Premiership fixtures.They will be in for some real battlesthey are to pick up points but they have fighters in their squad now which will give the Dee hope they can do it.No one less so than manager Jim McIntyre. He has marshalled a slight upturn in fortunes in recent weeks which has only been offset by the improved form of their relegation rivals Hamilton Accies and St Mirren, also.However, for Macca, it won’t be job done until Dundee are mathematically safe.And that is a long way off, as they sit in the relegation play-off place, three points behind Accies and only one ahead of the Buddies.Tonight, the Tele takes a look at the Dark Blues’ run-in to the split to see where they can pick up much-needed points.Dundee v Hearts # Saturday, March One of Dundee’s four wins this season, and their only one against a team which currently occupies the top six, came at Tynecastle at the end of January.That - success in Gorgie, coupled with the Jambos’ recent struggles – they are without a win in their last four league outings – will give the Dark Blues confidence going into Saturday’s clash at Dens Park.However, the Dee have only won once at home all season and need that to changethey are to have any hopes of staying in the ision.It’s must-win, for me, and I think they will rise to the occasion.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Celtic # Sunday, March A game in which Dundee will not be judged on come the end of the season but one,they keep it tight at the back, could see them sneak a valuable point.However, I fancy Celtic to go on a really good run as they look to wrap up eight titles in a row under new manager Neil Lennon.They’ll have too much.Verdict: No points.St Mirren v Dundee # Saturday, March One word. Ten letters. Hyphenated. Six-pointer.If the teams go into this one still practically neck and neck, which I expect they will, a win would be extremely valuable for both.However, I feel, with the enormity of the occasion, they will cancel each other out in Paisley.Verdict: One point.St Johnstone v Dundee # Wednesday, April The Dee and Saints have had some tasty encounters in recent seasons and this one should be no dferent with both teams likely to still have plenty to play for.St Johnstone may still be in the mix for the top six while Dundee’s situation is self-explanatory.I fancy the Dark Blues for this one, they play better on the road and have more to lose than the Perth men.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Aberdeen # Saturday, April You have to go back to November  for the last time Dundee got a win of any sorts against the Dons.That’s a run of  games without a win, with  losses in a row.That run has to end at some point, so I’ll back the Dee for a hard-earned draw.Verdict: One point.Total points: Eight points.That would leave Dundee with  going into the split and, you would like to think, put them in a decent position to stay up. That is, depending on how Hamilton and St Mirren get on with their fixtures .Hamilton – Motherwell , Hearts , Kilmarnock , Livingston , St Mirren .Verdict: Five points.St Mirren – Kilmarnock , St Johnstone , Dundee , Celtic , Hamilton .Verdict: Eight points.That would leave Hamilton level and St Mirren a point behind Dundee.

title: pals make meat loaf themed coffin to bid farewell to dundee entertainer marc
story: Friends of a Meat Loaf-loving entertainer came together to make sure he was given a fitting final farewell.Marc Kingston died suddenly last month at the age of , having had cancer.Born in Peterborough, he had lived in Dundee for more than  years and was a well-loved performer and DJ known as Marc Meat Loaf, who hosted events in the city.This week his friends met at Dundee Crematorium to make sure the performer received a fitting send-off.Marc arrived in a custom- made coffin painted with Meat Loaf’s Bat Out Of Hell album cover and driven in a flame-effect hearse. vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"  He was a huge fan of Meat Loaf, whose hits include I’d Do Anything For Love and Two Out of Three Ain’t Bad.The song Objects In The Rear View Mirror was played as guests left the service. Allan Middleton, who had known Marc for  years, helped to organise the funeral.The bespoke hearse was gted by Allan’s brother Angus’s company, Hearses Are Us, and the coffin was made by a company in England.Allan said: “Marc had seen the car in storage, he had admired it on several occasions and we just thought he liked it so it would be nicewe could use it rather than just a normal hearse.“The wake was in the Ambassador, which was close to his heart because he had done a lot of charity work and things there.“Affertons Funeral Care were brilliant. It was very important that he got a real send-off.”Allan said Marc was a generous man and was always looking to help other people.Marc was also well-known for his talented singing and was ruthless at school with those who he didn’t think were up to much – eventhey did go on to have particularly good careers.Tributes after sudden death of Marc, , one of Dundee#s #great entertainers#" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp tributes-after-sudden-death-of-marc--one-of-dundees-great-entertainers embed # secretisjMwEdx" data-secret"isjMwEdx" width"" "" title"#Tributes after sudden death of Marc, , one of Dundee#s #great entertainers## # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Allan said: “He did do a bit of opera when he was younger.“It was a part of him that Dundee didn’t know much about. These secrets came out at the crem. Fiona Riddle was the celebrant. She was fantastic. She went out of her way to make sure it was personalised.“In his first band at school, Marc threw out one of the singers because he thought he was talentless. That gentleman was Andy Bell of Erasure.”A fundraiser is to be held at the end of this month to help pay for the costs of the funeral and the coffin. Any money left over will go to Ninewells Cancer Campaign.Allan added that Marc loved his job and would often say he “couldn’t have a better way of le, I’m so lucky”.

title: Campaigners press on with vision for Inverness park
story: CAMPAIGNERS hoping to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space are pressing on with their vision, despite suffering a setback.The Northern Meeting Park Group hopes to transfer ownership of the venue in Ardross Street from Highland Council to a community-run organisation in a bid to enable greater public access and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildingsBut its application for a pound, grant to prepare a business plan and carry out surveys has been turned down by the Scottish Land Fund.Following feedback, however, it is now preparing to submit another application in May and is hoping for more positive news.It is also planning to open the usually locked park gates to the public for one week at Easter and another week in the school summer holidays.It is a repeat of a successful two-week trial opening last summer when hundreds took up the chance to enjoy the space for ious uses including family outings, outdoor office meetings and picnic lunches.Leading campaigner Jon Ford hopes to encourage greater use and activities during the opening weeks taking place April ndash and July ndash.ldquoThis year, we also want people to let us knowthey want to form a programme of events and we can seeit is something we can put on, he said.ldquoIf people are out and about in the park there might be a shinty game going on, for example, or a pipe band.Another possibility might be a Teddy bearsrsquo picnic.The group is also in talks with the Care and Learning Allianceabout future possibilities to use the location for childcare provision .In addition, discussions have taken place with the Calman Trust a young peoplersquos service offering housing support, training, employment opportunities, cooking services, about serving refreshments.Jaci Douglas, Calarsquos chief executive, said during discussions with the community over a year ago, flexible and accessible childcare was identied as one of the needs in the area along with a possible use for the park space.ldquoWe have been working closely with the Northern Meeting Park Group on how best to meet that aspiration, she said.ldquoAs an early years charity, Cala is well placed to work with partners to provide a quality early learning and childcare service and we are really excited about the opportunity to do that in close collaboration with the community group, Highland Council and Highland Le Highland as well as with local parents although itrsquos still at the early planning stages. ldquoSaturday  Mar  : AM

title: Candlelight tribute for Highland musician
story: A SOPRANO singer has paid tribute to her ldquospecial friend who inspired her to perform a candlelit concert to raise pound for a cancer care charity.Liz McLardy laid on an evening of music and song for Maggiersquos Highlands to show her admiration to staff who lted the spirits of her close friend Helen Sproston in the final days of her le.Mrs Sproston, a -year-old artist and musician who played alto saxophone in the Bonny Vista Social Club, and the Highland Swing band, would have been parted from her beloved Tibetan terrier called Mac had Maggiersquos not allowed friends to bring the dog in for visits while she was being treated at neighbouring Raigmore Hospital.The concert, called Baroque by Candlelight, in which Ms McLardy performed with pianist Tonya Clement and James Ross on clarinet, was held at St Johnrsquos Church in Inverness on February .Poignantly, Mrs Sproston passed away on the same day.Ms McLardy said: ldquoHelen was special. She was just so full of le. She did all sorts of outrageous things like climbing Mont Blanc and she travelled a lot.ldquoShe was a good artist and musician and she loved her little dog. She was unique. Yoursquod never have believed she was in her seventies.Mrs Sprostonrsquos ex-sister-in-law Kay Hall, with whom she attended Altrincham Grammar School in Cheshire, and had held a close bond as the pair married twin brothers, said Mrs Sproston has a son, Stuart, who lives in Barcelona. Her late husband Ron died several years ago.Paying her own tribute, she said: ldquoHelen was a free spirit and a very determined woman. Some people would say she was stubborn and that helped with the diagnosis. She was determined to make best use of the time that she had left.Bonny Vista Social Club guitarist Pete Gavin said he enjoyed Helenrsquos ldquohard-wit and her stoic approach to living and dying.He said: ldquoA couple of us in the band are aware of our own mortality for ious reasons and Helen was a good example for us because her attitude was very much like lsquoitrsquos time for the last song and Irsquom okay with thatrsquo.Fellow band members made a music recording for her, which she wanted to be played at her funeral.She also recorded a few final words which were edited into the track, thanking friends for all their love and good wishes and paying special thanks to the exceptional buddy who ldquosneaked in the GTs during visits.Then the music fades out with her laughter, Helenrsquos parting gt.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness College UHI lecturers on strike again
story: COLLEGE lecturers are on strike today after pay talks failed to produce any agreement.Members of the EIS Further Education Lecturersrsquo Association in Inverness have joined colleagues across Scotland in striking, with another strike set for March .It follows two one-day strikes earlier this year in pursuit of a cost of living pay increase.Picket lines were seen outside Inverness College UHI at Inverness Campus.Talks aimed at averting the strikes broke down without a resolution, leaving representatives for colleges exasperated, according to the Colleges Scotland Employersrsquo Association.John Gribben, the associationrsquos director of employment services, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has made it clear that there is no more money for lecturersrsquo pay and colleges have to find the pay deal on offer by making cuts.ldquoIf there were any more money available, our priorities would be for additional investment in enhancing studentsrsquo experiences and on further improving college campuses.Saturday  Mar  : AM
