title: cockburnspath-woman-meets-her-stem-cell-donor-on-itv-show
story: Laura Regan received a bone marrow transplant in  from an anonymous stem cell donor after being diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.Laura said that she thought about her donor often, adding: ldquoI knew it wouldnrsquot have been easy for him, having to re-arrange their le around the transplant.The -year-old was discovered by the ITV show This Time Next Year through her blog, in which she records the stages of her recovery.They filmed her saying that she would find her donor and they would appear on the show together a year later ndash which she did.The donor was a -year-old doctor named Simon Bird, and to her surprise they ended up living close to each other in London.ldquoThe first thing I did when I got Simonrsquos details was to look up his address on Google Maps," Laura said."It turned out that he lived just three miles away!ldquoEvery one of my friends told me I would be in tears but on the night, I couldnrsquot stop smiling."Simon was everything Irsquod hoped and imagined in real le and I was just so grateful to him for what hersquod done.ldquoWe were both keen to do the show to raise awareness for the Anthony Nolan Charity, who had helped me find a donor in the first place."Following filming, the pair have kept in touch. Laura said: ldquoWersquove been out for drinks. Wersquore both in long-term relationships, and Simon and his partner have invited me and my partner over for dinner. Wersquove become close.The episode, hosted by Davina McCall, will be aired tomorrowat .pm.

title: east-lothian-council-services-for-hire
story: The council is looking at ways to bring in extra revenue in the next three years by capitalising on its services and the influx of new housing in the county.Burial plots in two new cemeteries will be made available for advance sales as the council re-opens the pre-sale of lairs in Dunbar and Prestonpans, where capacity issues have seen the practice suspended in recent years. New housing developments in the towns have seen plans put forward for new graveyards to cope with the increasing populations.In Prestonpans, a proposed cemetery is included with plans to build  houses at Dolphingstone Farm while in Dunbar plans for a new graveyard at Newtonlees have been approved by the council.A council spokesperson said advance sales were withdrawn in the towns to ensure lairs were available for immediate need as they ran out of space.However, he confirmed: ldquoIt is expected that, as the new provision opens in Prestonpans and Dunbar, we will be in a position to process requests.As further new sites are developed, it is anticipated this option will become more widely available.It is anticipated the move will bring an additional pound, in revenue for the local authority in the next financial year as people queue up to book plots in their home towns.The move is one of a number of ventures which have been given the go-ahead in the councilrsquos budget plans for the next three years to maximise income.It also includes plans to bid to take over factoring contracts for landscaping in new housing developments and offer to install play equipment and areas in the same estates.The local authority is looking to capitalise on the influx of housing into the county, which is seeing up to , new homes being built across its communities.It hopes that it can compete with private factoring firms to take on responsibility for public areas within new housing estates, which developers traditionally hand on to independent factors.And it has budgeted a potential income of up to pound, by providing the commercial service over the next three years, as well as a further pound, by offering to install play areas in the new developments.The council said it was seeking to develop ldquocommercial opportunities across all services.The spokesman said: ldquoGiven the countyrsquos growth agenda, these are areas that we intend to explore.

title: man-who-slept-in-van-after-drinking-avoids-driving-ban
story: Mario Delacruz, , was caught sleeping in his van in an Edinburgh car park after he had been out drinking with friends in the city last year.Delacruz was spotted by police officers sleeping in the passenger seat of his van but they also saw his keys were lying nearby on the driverrsquos seat.The officers woke the Spanish national up and, after noticing he had been drinking alcohol, decided to breathalyse him.The tests showed that Delacruz, of The Promenade, was more than four times the drink-drive limit.Delacruz appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he pleaded guilty to being in charge of the vehicle at the time on October  last year.Solicitor Peter OrsquoNeill said that his client had been out with friends in the Leith area of the city and had decided to ldquosleep it off before going home the following day.Mr OrsquoNeill said that Delacruz had been in the UK for about five years and had moved to Scotland last July.He currently works as a cleaner and has sold the van he was found sleeping in.The lawyer added: ldquoHe is sorry and knows it should not have happened.Sherf John Cook fined Delacruz pound and told him that he would have  penalty points placed on his licence.Delacruz pleaded guilty to being in charge of a motor vehicle with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at Nichollfield, Edinburgh, on October  last year. The legal limit is  mcg.

title: conservatives-announce-haddington-by-election-candidate
story: Haddington resident Craig Hoy will represent the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party at the vote on May .The by-election was triggered by theresignation last week of Councillor Brian Small, who represented the Conservatives.Mr Hoy previously worked in journalism, first with the BBC before setting up several publications, including Holyrood Magazine.More recently, he has joined the development board of a major Scottish charity, which focuses on issues such as fuel poverty among older people.My Hoy was ldquodelighted to have been selected and looking forward to the election.He said: ldquoWith Nicola Sturgeon threatening a second independence referendum, itrsquos more important than ever that we elect a strong voice for Haddington and the Lammermuirs who will stand up to the SNP.ldquoAs a local resident and campaigner, Irsquom confident that I am well placed to do just that, and I look forward to taking our message to voters right across the ward over the coming weeks."And he added: "Our area has a fantastic sense of community and history.ldquoMy aim in this campaign is to meet as many people as possible to find out what their views are and what issues they want me to focus on.Tim Jackson, East Lothian Scottish Conservative Association chairman, was delighted to have secured ldquoa candidate of Craigrsquos calibre for the by-election.He said: ldquoNot only is he passionate about the area, but with his experience in media and business he can bring a lot to the council.ldquoI know he will give his all in the campaign, andelected he will do everything he can to provide a strong voice for everyone living in Haddington and the Lammermuirs.No other party has announced their candidate for the by-election.

title: port-seton-man-offers-to-clean-gardens-of-dog-waste
story: Super Pet Scooper was founded in January by Port Seton man Greg Mahony, of Laburnum Avenue, who will be servicing the East Lothian area for its doggy clear-up needs.ldquoI was looking for a business opportunity in the area, Greg said.ldquoCleaning gardens of dog waste is big in the USA and Canada, and even England, but not around here, so I saw a gap in the marketOriginally from Manchester, Greg and his family fell in love with all East Lothian had to offer, especially when walking his own rescue dog, Rocco. It was then he noticed that dog fouling in the area was becoming an issue.ldquoOur community wants to live in a nice environment, he said.ldquoWe promote responsible ownership, enforce fines and put up signs, but sometimes itrsquos just not enough.ldquoMany dog owners, like myself, always take doggie bags to clean up the waste, but sadly, many owners do not.This was when Greg came up with the idea for Super Pet Scooper.ldquoI never thought Irsquod start a business, but I wanted to do something that would help people and I love animals, especially dogs, so it made sense, he said.ldquoI donrsquot mind cleaning up after dogs, it doesnrsquot bother me! It also gets me out and about on a weekend, as well as a little more income.Greg works during the week for the NHS but has high hopes that he can build his company to a full-time role.ldquoAt the moment, Irsquom only part-time but Irsquom hoping to expand, he said.ldquoI got in touch with East Lothian Council for advice and they were fantastic, helped me get my waste carrier licence and advice on business insurance and things.Despite only being in his first month of business, the -year-old has a few clients and has been getting good reviews across Facebook.ldquoIrsquove had a positive reaction to the company, he said. ldquoI know a lot of people think thatyou have a dog you should be able to clean up after them yourself, but a lot of people canrsquot. They can fall ill or just become unable to move around like they used to, so thatrsquos where I can help.

title: ghost-hunters-heading-to-historic-east-lothian-buildings
story: The two events will be taking place in the coming months.Lisa Tedstill, company owner of UK Ghost Nights said: ldquoItrsquos all about the personal experience, the emotions, and sometimes the giggling and laughing. Itrsquos about the camaraderie. Itrsquos a great way to view history, and there have been many spooky things happening in these places.The night involves a tour of the building by a medium, then the chance to use high-tech ghost hunting equipment for experiments, as well as more standard methods such as seances and spirit boards.ldquoWe like to give people a chance to see and use lots of new things and provide a good mix of the technical and the traditional, added Lisa.ldquoItrsquos great here in East Lothian as there is so much history in these buildings.The ghost hunts are at Dunbar Town House on March  and Cockenzie House on April , both pm-am.

title: pupils-to-enjoy-unique-study-visit-to-oxford-university
story: Exeter College has teamed up with East Lothian Council to bring  third-year pupils to the university for a stay which will allow them to experience first-hand the unique learning techniques and opportunities available there.The project was established by former Councillor East Lothian Brian Small and his son Andrew, who is a doctoral student at the college and came up with the idea.Brian, of Pencaitland, said the pair now hoped to establish an endowment fund to ensure the trip can become an annual event for East Lothian students by providing travel costs and other support.This yearrsquos trip will see the local authority fund travel with the college covering all costs of the stay itself.Mr Small, who resigned from the council last week after branding his fellow Conservative councillors ldquoheartless over the way they dealt with his battle with health issues, said he wanted to make sure money was available to repeat the project every summer.He said: ldquoI am delighted we have been able to start this innovative project as pathways for all our children in East Lothian was always something I was fully committed to as a councillor.ldquoI am now looking to set up an endowment fund to ensure travel costs along with perhaps some other support needs are able to be covered in future years.ldquoIf anyone would like to discuss this further then I would be delighted to talk with them.Two pupils from each of East Lothianrsquos six secondary schools will travel to Oxford in June for the week-long stay.The selected students will live on Exeter Collegersquos historic main site, in the very heart of Oxford, where they will be given a taster experience of what makes an Oxford education.The council said interested pupils were now given a chance to apply for a place in the trip with places awarded by teachers following a selection procedure involving written work.Andrew said: ldquoThis is a fantastic opportunity for pupils from East Lothian to come and learn at one of the worldrsquos greatest educational institutions.ldquoThe weekrsquos activities have been selected to improve pupilsrsquo independent and creative thinking, which we hope will improve their attainment at school and perhaps even plant the seed of aspiration that will motivate pupils to attend the university.ldquoMy hope is that this is just the beginning of a long-standing partnership between the college and East Lothian.ldquoI would like to thank Sir Rick Trainor, Rector of Exeter College and Professor Mac Niocaill, the collegersquos Tutor for Admissions, for their full support. Without them, this partnership would have remained just an idea.Fiona Robertson, head of education, East Lothian Council, said the trip offered a rare opportunity for young people in the county to study at one of the worldrsquos top universities.She said: ldquoI hope the  pupils involved will find it to be an inspirational trip and one which allows them to develop their independent, creative thinking and commitment to learning. I would like to thank Andrew Small and his father, Brian Small, for making this a reality.

title: 1000-sign-petition-over-loss-of-creche-services-at-leisure-centres
story: The organisation manages leisure facilities across the county on behalf of East Lothian Council.However, it has taken the decision to close the creches following a drop in funding.The move has not gone down well with a number of parents, who fear they may have to cancel their gym membershipsthe creche service does not continue.A group of parents met with Iain Gray, East Lothianrsquos MSP, on Monday to discuss the issue.Among them was Sarah Brunton, who regularly uses enjoyleisurersquos facilities in North Berwick, Haddington and Dunbar.The mum-of-four said she had improved her fitness at the facilities since having her children. She said: ldquoItrsquos down to those facilities and being able to have a healthier lestyle.ldquoIt is about not just weight loss but also a mental health aspect. It gives you confidence and a lt after you have done exercise and it is proven that exercise does improve mental health.Mrs Brunton stressed the issue affected ldquoa lot of people and many were considering whether to cancel their membership.Another of those who has signed the online petition is -year-old Erin Malone, who uses the Aubigny Sports Centre, in Haddington, and Tranentrsquos Loch Centre.She said: ldquoThe creche is really important ndash not just for me but my son as well.ldquoMy daughter used it as well and we have been using it for over six years.ldquoIt is a social thing and a mental health thing as well.Lydia Eunson, from Dunbar, uses the sports centre in Dunbar twice a week.She added: ldquoMy husband works away four weeks at a time and I donrsquot have any family near here.ldquoBasically, I could not use the gym unless I paid a babysitter or went to a gym in Edinburgh with a creche.Bill Axon, general manager of enjoyleisure, stressed it was not a decision that was taken lightly, with discussions taking place with trade unions and no date set for any creche closure.He said: ldquoWe truly appreciate that the cregraveche service, which is supervised by highly-regarded staff, is an incredibly valued service by those who make use of it.ldquoIt is because of this fact, that the decision to withdraw this service has been so incredibly dficult.ldquoOver the past  years, since enjoyrsquos creation, we have retained this service for the benefit of our customers, despite operating at a shortfall.ldquoHowever, as user numbers continue to decline year upon year, the subsequent financial deficit has increased strain on the rest of the organisation.ldquoGiven the funding reductions and additional financial challenges faced by enjoy this year, we have reached the point where we simply cannot continue to subsidise a deficit of this magnitude.ldquoAdditionally, strict adult to child ratios and current charging requirements reduce our capacity of increasing income for this service, and at existing user levels, it is not possible to retain this provision at an affordable cost to customers.Mr Gray has got in touch with enjoyleisure to highlight the ious concerns.Mr Gray said: ldquoI met with a group of women campaigning against the cregraveche closures and listened very carefully to their concerns.ldquoItrsquos clear that whatever the reasons for the withdrawal of the cregraveche service, it will have a signicant impact on those who currently use it.ldquoI have now written to enjoyleisure to highlight the concerns raised with me and ask for a response.Councillor Stuart Currie, leader of the SNP Group on East Lothian Council, was similarly unimpressed with the decision to scrape the creches.He said the SNP Group was supporting the petition calling for enjoyleisure to think again.The Musselburgh councillor said: ldquoIn Haddington, Musselburgh and every other town this damaging decision will hit many people, particularly women, the hardest.Council leader Willie Inneshas written to Gordon Wales, chairman of the enjoyleisure board, to express his concern about the proposed changes.He said: "Following concerns expressed to me by regular users of enjoyleisure facilities about the closure of cregraveches I have written to Gordon Wales outlining the councils position about the importance of access to leisure facilities.ldquoCregraveches provide an important resource for families to be able to fully access a range of leisure activities and I hope alternative measures can be considered."To sign the petition, go to you.degrees.org.uk petitions keep-our-creche

title: plans-lodged-to-turn-former-dunbar-rbs-into-a-sweet-shop
story: Gavin and Susan Love, of Love Sweets and Ices, plan to open a second sweet shop on Dunbar High Street, with a shop within the former Royal Bank of Scotlandpremises.The national bank moved out of  High Street last May, with the premises lying empty ever since.Now plans have been submitted to East Lothian Council looking for alterations to be carried out and the building to be turned into a shop and cafe with outdoor seating.Drawings included in the planning application show little in the way of changes inside the building, with internal walls remaining in place.A seating area would be included at the rear of the building, with benches outside the front in a fenced-off seating area.A managerrsquos office would also be created to the front of the building.Gavin Love, who along with we Susan runs the business at its existing premises of  High Street, said: ldquoThings have been progressing really well.ldquoOur initial plan was to open in March but we have now decided to add some internal seating for sit-in ice cream and we now intend to open in late April early May.Mr and Mrs Love intend to run both shops and use the additional space to provide a wider range of traditional specialised confectionery products and ice cream.Drawings included within the planning application suggest a new lsquoThe Sweetie Bankrsquo sign could be created outside the business.The plans were first highlighted at the townrsquos community council meeting in November last year.Pippa Swan, the grouprsquos chairwoman, was hopeful the business would prove to be a great success.She said: ldquoI had no idea there was such a demand for sweeties and scrumptious things but what a wonderful, fun use of a great building. Irsquom looking forward to it and I am sure it will be a good addition to the street.The bank branch closure was one of  RBS and  NatWest branches to shut following a decision at the end of .The move was widely criticised by local politicians and members of the public, with North Berwickrsquos RBS also closing.

title: belhaven-bays-baywatch-to-patrol-the-beach-this-summer
story: A grant of pound, has been given to Dunbar Surf Le Saving Clubto run the project, which will see training given to volunteers, as well as raising awareness of the risks associated with the coast.The money, from the Big Lottery Fund, will ensure the Dunbar organisation is the first of its kind in Scotland to run a volunteer Beach Surf Lesaving Patrol.Sally Harris, head coach of DSLSC, told the Courier: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to receive this funding from the National Lottery.ldquoWe will now be able to put together Scotlandrsquos first community-led voluntary surf lesaving beach patrol team in Dunbar.ldquoThe funding will also allow us to continue our preventative education programme, helping to reduce the national coastal drowning statistics.The aims of the Belhaven Bay Community Le Saving Beach Patrol are to provide a lesaving service for the community and visitors, to prevent accidental drowning and injury among beach users.Training will also be given to young people and adults in the community to deliver the services while also raising awareness of the risks associated with using the beach and sea.In , more than  people drowned in the UK.Belhaven Bay, within John Muir Country Park, is a favourite spot for surfers, open-water swimmers and water sports enthusiasts from across the country and beyond.The Beach Patrol will initially operate during the busy summer weekends.Dunbar and East Linton ward member Councillor Norman Hampshire welcomed the scheme.He said: ldquoAs the local ward councillor, I am delighted that Belhaven lsquoBaywatchrsquo with Scotlandrsquos first volunteer Beach Patrol Service are going to start this year.ldquoI would like to congratulate them on their successful application to the Big Lottery.ldquoThis will provide some good training opportunities for young people and adults in the area.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, wished the club the best of luck.He said: ldquoIt is a worthwhile objective andit makes the beach safer one must applaud it.

title: world-champion-sprinter-maria-lyle-thanks-her-mum-for-rekindling-her-love-of-athletics
story: Maria Lyle ed from the Fazza International Championships in Dubai recently with two gold medals.However, it was just last year that she broke down in tears during her ldquodarkest moment before a major competition.The teenager has lived with diplegic cerebral palsy in her legs almost all her le.The -year-old told the Courier that her mum Susan had been with her throughout her journey, which has seen her represent Great Britain in the Paralympics and Scotland in the Commonwealth Games.Her mum is a PE teacher at Dunbar Primary School and taught Maria.Keen for Maria to be involved as much as her peers, but with little experience of teaching pupils with a disability, Susan looked for ways to deliver lessons which allowed Maria to flourish.Maria said: ldquoWhen I was younger, I struggled quite a lot. Things didnrsquot come quite as naturally for me as they did for my peers and often I ended up feeling a bit rubbish about myself.ldquoThings drastically changed, however, after one PE lesson. We had to complete the multi-stage fitness test .ldquoAs someone who fell over constantly and ended up with cut knees  per cent of the time, you could say I wasnrsquot that keen to join the lesson.ldquoTo everyonersquos surprise, I was the last one left in the test. That was the first time Irsquod ever felt such a sense of achievement. From that moment, running would become a big part of my le.Those short runs started to build Mariarsquos strength.She became European champion in  and within the next four years Paralympic, World and Commonwealth medals followed.But despite all her success, Maria couldnrsquot find the same love for her sport as she had during those early runs with her mum. The teenager became overwhelmed with worry about competing and her concerns impacted her le away from the track.After suffering in silence for years, Maria finally opened up to her mum, who convinced her to seek professional help. She was later diagnosed with having anxiety.Maria, who works at the Scottish Parliament as a committee assistant, said: ldquoMy mum would give up lots of her time, she would lead my sessions and drive me all over the country so I could compete. She would even take time off work to watch me in competitions. Because of this I would get worriedI didnrsquot run well.ldquoIrsquod feel guilty about wasting her time. Disappointing my mum wasnrsquot the only thing I was anxious about. I was worried about my competitors and factors I couldnrsquot control.ldquoBefore the  European Championships, I revealed something to my mum that I had never spoken about before. I broke down and cried for hours expressing how rubbish I felt about myself in both my running and personal le.ldquoRunning had completely taken over and there was nothing positive.ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me.ldquoShe was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me. From that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.Susan said that no medal ceremony could compare to seeing her daughter enjoying running again. She said: ldquoMy proudest moment is not Maria winning medals on the world stage, it is probably Maria competing in Glasgow last weekend at the  National Indoor Championships.ldquoFor the first time in years, I saw Maria stand on the start line feeling relaxed and running through the finish line with a smile on her face.ldquoAlong with the support from us as a family and her coach, Jamie Bowie, Maria has turned herself around and is back on track in all areas of her le.

title: little-support-for-idea-of-public-wi-fi-in-town-centres
story: A report to East Lothian Council revealed that moves to increase access to a fast, free public internet service did not win favour with residents.Despite the lack of support, council officers are pushing ahead with their strategy to introduce it across towns in the county.The report into the local authorityrsquos town centre strategy revealed the results of public consultations over a range of actions proposed within the communities.It said: ldquoFor each town centre there was overall support for all the proposed actions, with the exception of the introduction of public Wi-Fi in each town centre, except Haddington which already has public Wi-Fi.In Musselburgh, two-thirds of respondents disagreed with a proposal to introduce it in the town centre, with less than a third agreeing in Tranent. The reaction was similar in Prestonpans and North Berwick, while Dunbar saw the least support, with only one in five backing it.In the majority of towns, the most support was to use statutory action to force private owners of buildings in multiple ownership to have external repairs carried out.Among comments about public Wi-Fi relayed to councillors, one person said: ldquoI really find it surprising that town Wi-Fi has been identied as a possible benefit for the town centre. With excellent G coverage in the town, this would perhaps be more suited at the end of the list of improvements.Another added: ldquoI donrsquot think lack of public Wi-Fi is an issue with G cover widely available.But the council responded: ldquoThe council notes that even with  per centsuperfast broadband coverage [the same goes for G G], affordability will remain a signicant challenge. Consequently, there will still be a requirement for free Wi-Fi across our communities.

title: musselburgh-golf-club-hopes-to-attract-more-women-members
story: Head professional Norman Huguet will lead lessons for women interested in learning to play golf and they will also get the chance to practise their skills on the clubrsquos stand-alone par  beginnersrsquo course.Committee member Linda Smith has organised the initiative, which starts with an open event at the club next Sunday , -pm and -pm.Women can join others also considering taking up golf in a relaxed atmosphere. Everyone is entered into a draw for a free afternoon tea at the club.A block of six lessons for one hour a week then start in April, with clubs provided and trainers allowed. During this time, players have full access to the beginnersrsquo course and all other practice areas.The tuition for a maximum of  women is held on a Tuesday, starting on April , and also on a Wednesday, beginning April , -pm. More classes will be organisedthere is demand.Linda said: ldquoWe want to give people an easy and cheap way to try golf.ldquoPeople might think they need to get golf shoes and equipment. If you decide you want to play, yoursquod get those things over time but, to try golf, you donrsquot need them as we will provide the clubs. We want to take away those barriers.ldquoThere might be a lot of women who would like to try golf but donrsquot know how to go about it.ldquoGroup lessons are a nice way for women to learn and, once the lessons are finished, they have a nice, ready-made group of people that they know in the golf club. So,they go on to join the club, they have people they can play with.ldquoWe will make sure the ladies, during the lessons and after, are integrated into the club. That is something we want to focus on because there is playing on the golf course but there is the golf club which is a dferent thing.ldquoPeople can come into the clubhouse and enjoy the tray bakes and scones, have a coffee and a chat with people, and meet new friends.Linda said the ladiesrsquo section was small with just over  members who play.She added: ldquoDuring the six-week lessons, lady members will help with the lessons and then we can go for a tea or coffee after, so people will be comfortable coming into the clubhouse.ldquoExisting members will also play with the ladies involved in the lessons on the six-hole course.ldquoThe six-hole par- course is great. No one is going to go and watch you playing there. If you miss-hit the ball, which you will when you are learning, there is no one to see you other than other learners.ldquoIt is a non-scary place to learn to play golf.ldquoWe are a really friendly club and people will be made very welcome. If people like it, after the six-week period, they can join the six-hole course or join and be able to play on the championship course.ldquoWe are just hoping that there are enough people out there who want to come and learn.Linda stressed that there were dferent s mapped out on the championship course, including a shorter blue course.Linda said: ldquoThey can play thethey feel is suitable for them.ldquoWe want people to come in and make new friends and use the clubhouse facilities.ldquoIf people want to come and only focus on getting their handicaps down because they are competitive golfers, thatrsquos great as well and there are places for that. consignment reference numberndash A simplied electronic customs declaration systemndash Mobile control and inspection unitsndash Border surveillance using automated number plate recognition and CCTV.Mr Murrison said:ldquoTime is running out toreachcommon ground.ldquoThere should be no attempt to use the border as a lever or as a way of securing political advantage.ldquoMistrust over the title: Iain Macwhirter  28 days to go and Westminster won   t even reject no deal  let alone back a People   s Vote
story: I could give you a pious expression of naive hope. Tell you that therersquos going to be a referendum on Brexit, that the ERG are back in their box, Jezza has finally come good, and Theresa May has been put in a secure unit. But I canrsquot in all honesty agree with commentators, like the blessed Polly Toynbee, who believe we are now on the road to redemption.Yes, Labour did repeat its promise to hold a referendumJeremy Corbynrsquos ldquoworkable plan of a permanent customs union is rejected ndash as it was in one of last weekrsquos many meaningless votes. Oh, and Labour will support a referendumthere is no General Election. Anda no deal Tory deal looks likely. If, , .ButLabour really wanted to eliminate the threat of no deal, it would have moved heaven and earth to deliver the SNPrsquos motion calling for precisely that.Looking back on this dismal week, the standout, surely, is the arrant insanity of Parliament ndash a rational body of elected representatives ndash failing to take the opportunity to rule out an event which would put the army on the streets, interrupt food and medicine supplies, and cause the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.Yes, the Yvette Cooper Oliver Letwin amendmentwas endorsed by Parliament overwhelmingly, after Theresa May gave it the nod. This means that there will be an extension to Article Parliament doesnrsquot support a deal by March . Well and good. If therersquos one thing the UK Parliament is supremely good at itrsquos failing to agree.It doesnrsquot like Mayrsquos botched deal, the Norway option, EFTA or any other solution that Brussels thinks acceptable. So that means an extension is inevitable. Except that the French president Emmanuel Macron and the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, have made clear that the  countries of the EU , will only contemplate delaying Britainrsquos departure from the EUit is for ldquoa purpose. Holding more meaningless votes, staging more ministerial resignations and arguing on College Green outside Parliament do not, one suspects, constitute a legitimate purpose.Still, everyone seems convinced that an extension is in the bag. This led to largely unwarranted excitement on the Remain side. With Labour calling for a Peoplersquos Voteand Theresa Mayrsquos deadline finally breached, Twitter went into orbit. Lord Adonis all but declared victory in the Battle of Brexit. Europhiles were dancing in the streets, metaphorically at least, and jeering at the nasty Brexiters who had been defeated by the forces of good. It was like the last reel of Lord of the Rings.But such triumphalism was premature. Much as I wish it were the case, there is still no majority in Parliament for a referendum. Stephen K Bush, the political editor of the New Statesman, has been counting them out and counting them back in again and he is adamant that the Labour Brexit rebels will prevent any motion for a referendum passing through Parliament. He says at least  Labour MPs are opposed. Hersquos right.ldquoRebels here is something of a misnomer since there is widespread belief that Brexit is the outcome desired by their leader. Indeed, on one interpretation of last weekrsquos events, Jeremy Corbyn has managed to find a way to secure Brexit while also appearing to support a referendum. This is because what is called the Kyle Wilson amendment.This cross-party proposal, which Labour is minded to support on March , calls for MPs to agree to Theresa Mayrsquos deal , but only on the condition that there is a referendum to validate it. Bingo. Labour can tell all its working-class Brexit supporters in target marginals that, yes, it didnrsquot block Brexit. But Jeremy can also curry favour with the Remainiacs of Islington by appearing to support a Peoplersquos Vote.Itrsquos very clever, but to my mind somewhat bonkers. Why would Labour help pass Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which Jeremy Corbyn has said is worse than no deal, would lose thousands of jobs and would lock the UK into a backstop from which it cannot escape  At least this is what he has said repeatedly in the Commons.Surely, a vote is a vote. Theresa May could legitimately say that her deal has been endorsed by Parliament, and call on Labour to campaign for it in any referendum. Not that she has the slightest intention of calling a referendum.Theresa Mayrsquos strategy is the same as it ever was: not listening, nothing has changed, take it or leave it. It pains me to say it, but the Prime Minister at least has a strategy. It is to run down the clock, while allowing the ious tribes in Parliament and in her Cabinet, to fall out among themselves.Itrsquos working. Labour is moving ever more in the direction of her deal, however much they may deny it. Parliament canrsquot agree on anything.There are tears in Cabinet and more resignations ndash  from the Government so far. But whorsquos counting  The European Research Group ndash that comically misnamed faction of extreme Brexiters ndash has reportedly split over William Rees-Moggrsquos equivocation on the Irish backstop.And while all about is chaos and acrimony, so ticks away the clock until Brexit day. Twenty-eight days at the time of writing. Goodness me, is that really the time  Yes it is. As in the film of the same name, the zombies are stirring.I accept that is an offensive way to describe Nigel Faragersquos ldquoBrexit Betrayal march from Sunderland to London. But it could get nasty on the road.What do I think will happen in the end  As Irsquove been saying in this column since Christmas, I think Parliament will block a no-deal Brexit. There will be an extension of Article , and Labour will probably end up backing Mayrsquos deal, or abstaining on it which amounts to the same thing.If Labour, by some remote chance, continues to reject Mayrsquos deal or its iants, in the meaningful vote on the inglorious twelfth, then I think MPs would still reject a referendum. There is still no majority for one, and Labourrsquos die-hard Brexiters are not for turning.Which makes the most likely option ndash about the only one Theresa May can authorise as PM under her prerogative powers ndash would be to revoke Article . Pull the plug. End it.OK, so thatrsquos wishful thinking on my part. Her Government would fall and precipitate an election. But looking at the chaos that is Brexit, and the lack of time, it seems as good a shout as any, especiallyBrussels reject a meaningless extension.If Britain canrsquot decide how to leave the EU, an extension to Article  would be pointless. The sensible thing to do would be to cancel Brexit, go away, and think again.

title: health-secretary-jeane-freeman-convinced-mesh-ban-was-correct-decision
story: Health boards in Scotland were ordered to immediately halt the use of vaginal mesh implants in September, with thousands of women having received the treatment.Many women say they have suffered painful and debilitating health complications as a result of the procedure.The use of mesh was suspended in all but ldquoextraordinary circumstances in Scotland in .:Mesh victims make emotional plea for help to Scottish GovernmentThe Scottish Government said a sub-group of medical directors and senior clinical managers will be asked to consider a range of measures to help improve care for women who have received a mesh implant.Ms Freeman said: ldquoLast September, I announced a complete halt to all transvaginal mesh procedures and that will only be lted when I am satisfied that a high vigilance, restricted-use protocol has been fully implemented.ldquoI remain convinced that was the right decision but it is also important that we do everything possible for the women who have suffered injury as a result of complications from procedures already carried out.ldquoFollowing this weekrsquos debate at the Scottish Parliament, I have listened carefully to the views of women who have been affected by complications.ldquoI had the opportunity to meet some of them in person after the debate and I found what they told me of their experience deeply moving.She added: ldquoThis sub-group will look at a range of options to see how the care and support for these women can be improved.ldquoIn particular, and where reasonable, I want them to ensure that women have some choice regarding the place of treatment and the clinicians involved.ldquoSenior health board medical managers, academic and European advisers, and advocates for the affected women will all contribute to this work.ldquoThe first meeting will be held as soon as is practicable and I will write to campaigners within a month to set out the probable timescales.:Health secretary calls a halt to use of mesh implants in ScotlandAmong the grouprsquos considerations will be the sharing of experience and techniques from Europe and the US, and examining education and training requirements.The Scottish Government said a meeting with a representative group of campaigners will be arranged to seek their views on service development.Scottish Conservative interim leader Jackson Carlaw said he welcomed the announcement from the Health Secretary.:Jackson Carlaw claims Ruth Davidson will be First Minister in two yearsldquoThis is a step forward for women in Scotland seeking full mesh removal and is a great result for campaigners ndash Elaine Holmes, Olive McIlroy and Marion Scott, he said.ldquoThis announcement opens the door to more clinical working with mesh experts in other parts of the world.ldquoThis battle has been a protracted one but this does look like a victory.ldquoI now very much hope that the SNP Government will stick to their word and give mesh survivors these much-needed options.

title: theresa-may-uk-may-never-leave-eu-if-brexit-deal-rejected
story: In a warning ahead of Tuesdays Commons showdown on her Withdrawal Agreement, the Prime Minister acknowledged "no one knows" what will happenher plan is defeated.The Prime Minister is urging Brussels to give ground in order to help her deal survive Tuesdays crunch vote by agreeing changes to the Northern Ireland backstop measures.:Ian McConnell: Tory Government panders to Labour Leavers and DUP on BrexitIn a speech in Leave-voting Grimsby, the Prime Minister said: "Next week MPs in Westminster face a crucial choice: Whether to back the Brexit deal or to reject it."Back it and the UK will leave the European Union. Reject it and no one knows what will happen."We may not leave the EU for many months, we may leave without the protections that the deal provides. We may never leave at all."She added: "Everyone now wants to get it done, move beyond the arguments, past the bitterness of the debate and out of the EU as a united country ready to make a success of the future."In a plea to Brussels for support in making changes, she said what the European Union does over the next few days "will have a big impact on the outcome of the vote".Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned Brussels that a failure to co-operate on securing changes to the Brexit deal could "poison" relations with the EU for years."This is a moment of change in our relationship between the UK and the EU and history will judge both sides very badlywe get this wrong," Mr Hunt told the BBC Radio  Today programme."We want to remain the best of friends with the EU. That means getting this agreement through in a way that doesnt inject poison into our relations for many years to come."The EU said technical discussions are ongoing and it insisted Brussels has come forward with ideas to resolve the deadlock.:Negotiators to work through weekend to break the deadlock in the Brexit talksEuropean Commission spokesman Alex Winterstein told reporters in Brussels: "The EU side has offered ideas on how to give further reassurances regarding the backstop. You are aware of all this."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Prime Minsiters speech was "a sign of desperation" and promised to oppose the deal again when it came to the Commons, instead continuing to push his own proposals for a customs union and access to the single market.He said his partys priority was to stop a no-deal Brexit, but insisted Labour was not "backing away" from a second referendum."What were saying is the priority at this moment is to stop a no-deal exit."

story: Mrs Thatcher, who famously slept for only four hours a night, received ldquonutrimental capsules from the novelist ldquoin case you ever feel tired.On a separate occasion Mrs Thatcher was sent a further supplement, possibly to address jetlag or travel sickness ahead of a trip to the Far East.Dame Barbara, who corresponded with Mrs Thatcher fairly regularly and lunched with her, sent a package dated June  .ldquoMy dear Prime Minister, You were wonderful last night, as usual, she wrote.ldquoIt is incredible, with all you do, how you can still look as though you were .ldquoIn case you ever feel tired, I am enclosing the very latest product we have in the Health Movement, which takes oxygen to every part of the body, including the brain.ldquoMy son, aged , says that he wakes up in the morning and feels like a boy of , and at nearly  I find it fantastic.In a letter dated June  , Mrs Thatcher thanked Dame Barbara for the ldquocharming letter and the ldquonutrimental capsules.Dame Barbara wrote to Mrs Thatcherrsquos diary secretary Amanda Ponsonby on July   with further supplements ahead of Mrs Thatcherrsquos planned trip to the Far East.ldquoThank you so much for being most kind and saying that you will give the enclosed to the Prime Minister, wrote Dame Barbara.ldquoI hope that there are enough because it is a very long trip.ldquoI did it myself and it does feel ghastly when you get home.ldquoDo impress on her that as far as I know there are no side-effects at all, and they are not soporic, so that you feel you must go to sleep.ldquoIt just stops that awful feeling in the head and earshellipMillionaire industrialist Sir Emmanuel Kaye, once a strong supporter of the Conservative Party, wrote to Mrs Thatcher after seeing her at the opera at Glyndebourne offering advice about her supplements.He said he could ldquosort out vitamins, minerals etc and,you like hellip check whether the Vitamin C and the Royal Jelly you are having are of the best iety for you and work out the optimum dosage.Sir Emmanuel also mentioned he had evolved ldquoan advanced form of homeopathy called body tuning, though it is not known whether he did any for Mrs Thatcher.The same year, a profile titled The Blooming Of Margaret Thatcher appeared in Vanity Fair, claiming Mrs Thatcher was fond of ldquoelectric baths ndash in which . amps of electricity was run through water in a bid to stay youthful.Chris Collins, of the Margaret Thatcher Foundation, said: ldquoThe impression of dottiness, of a woman lsquoslightly off her trolleyrsquo, was not one thatIngham could treat lightly and the lsquoelectric baths piecersquo attracted a lot of attention one way or another in the worldrsquos press.He said that references to health cures in Mrs Thatcherrsquos correspondence were ldquoobscure, perhaps deliberately so, adding that he believed her interest was genuine.The Margaret Thatcher Foundation is gradually overseeing the release of her private files through the Churchill Archives Centre in Cambridge.Members of the public will be able to browse the archive from Monday by visiting www.margaretthatcher.org

title: technical-solutions-could-avoid-infrastructure-on-irish-border-post-brexit-say-mps
story: A highly sophisticated ldquoworld first would be necessary to achieve such a system during a -month transition period after an orderly exit, the Westminster inquiry found.It could include a mobile phone identication system enabling remote ID checking as well as a previously suggested trusted trader scheme, expert evidence to the Government scrutiny body said.The Northern Ireland Affairs Committee also called on UK and EU negotiators to agree on a definition of a hard border.Chairman Andrew Murrison said: ldquoMy committeetook good evidence to suggest that technical and systems-based solutions to ensure the border looks and feels as it does today are do-able but they require trust and goodwill.Unless something changes, the UK is set to exit the EU without a deal later this month.Avoiding a hard border and resolving the dispute over the ldquobackstop insurance policy keeping Northern Ireland in line with EU regulationsno other trade solution is foundis the key sticking point in reaching agreement before March .The committee published its report on Saturday.It took evidence fromthe former director of capacity building at the World Customs Organisation, Lars Karlsson, on proposals for managing the flow of goods on the island of Ireland.Mr Karlsson saidall the separate elements which make up the proposal ldquohave been tested somewhere in the world just not in one single border and the border in Northern Ireland would be ldquothe first and a leading example in the world of this kind.His proposal included:ndash A bilateral EU-UK agreement on advanced customs cooperationndash Mutual recognition of trusted tradersndash A technical agreement on exchange of customs risk datandash An identication system by the border using either the mobile phone network or radio frequency identication to check goods or driver ID without leaving the vehiclendash A digital single entry point for traders addressing import and export mattersndash Creation of a unique consignment reference numberndash A simplied electronic customs declaration systemndash Mobile control and inspection unitsndash Border surveillance using automated number plate recognition and CCTV.Mr Murrison said:ldquoTime is running out toreachcommon ground.ldquoThere should be no attempt to use the border as a lever or as a way of securing political advantage.ldquoMistrust over the backstop protocol has been heightened by lack of clarity onwhat exactly constitutes a lsquohard border.rsquoldquoMy committee is calling for claricationof the term in a legally explicit way to ensure both parties share the same understanding of how the backstop can be avoided.

title: new premises for support firms
story: Aberdeenshire-based oil field equipment suppliers, Cable Solutions Worldwide Ltd and ESWL, are expanding their businesses and moving their head offices to Blackhall Industrial Estate in Inverurie.With support from a six-figure funding package from Royal Bank of Scotland, the recently completed office, co-owned by the companies, will allow the leading design and manufacturers of bespoke cable solutions to expand into the international oil and gas market.Cable Solutions Worldwide Ltd provides both off-the-shelf and bespoke design, manufacturing, supply and project management facilities to the oil and gas, subsea, ship building and renewable energy sectors.It is hoped the larger, purpose-built space will increase productivity and allow the firm to take on more staff, in addition to widening its product reach.ESWL, a procurement company to the local and international energy sector, also hopes to expand its sales and engineering team in the next year.Colin Fraser, director of Cable Solutions Worldwide, said: “We’ve come through a relatively turbulent period within the subsea and oil and gas sectors and are now looking to expand into more robust markets.“The purpose-built facility will allow us to increase the cable assembly process, provide more erse products, stock more of our customers’ favourites and provide jobs to the local economy.”Iain Dougary, director of ESWL, added: “It’s positive to see other north east businesses growing and confidence ing to the sector. Our new Inverurie premises will allow us to strengthen our existing team, by hiring new team members in our sales and engineering workshop.”Martin Ramsay, relationship director at Royal Bank of Scotland, said the move is indicative of growing confidence in the industry. He said: “The growth plans of both companies are prime examples of confidence ing to the oil and gas sector within Scotland, benefitting the local economy.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"CE marking after Brexit"  CE marking after Brexit viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: inverurie screwfix shop is approved
story: Councillors have approved plans for the erection of a shop on the site of the former IK Motors yard on Inverurie#s Blackhall Industrial Estate.Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee heard on Tuesday that the site, which was formerly used for car sales by IK Motors, is currently unused with all sales now taking place at Highclere Business Park.The new building will be occupied by Screwfix and while the main market served by the company is trade sales, the premises would also be open to members of the public Monday to Friday from am to pm, Saturday from am to pm and Sunday from am to pm.Councillors heard that the proposal would create  jobs.The wider site currently accommodates a number of outlets including the likes of Morrisons, the Strathburn Hotel, Firework Scotland Ltd, Magpie Second Hand Furniture, William Wilson Plumbing Centre andthe Fly Cup Coffee Shop. A number of alternative sites had been discounted as a result of being either too large, too small, or unavailable.A planning report to committee stated: “The proposals would provide both local trades and members of the public with a range of DIY products from an established home improvement company and thus can be considered as a benefit to the local community.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.berwickshirenews webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Charity representatives at the launch of Run Garioch "  Charities hold last entries to Run GariochviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.berwickshirenews webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The fountain is located in Kintore Town Centre"  Summerfor Kintore fountain viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Air traffic controllers at Wick could strike next month
story: AIR traffic controllers at Wick John OGroats Airport could go on strike next month in a bid to get an improved pay deal.They and their Highlands and Islands colleagues in the Prospect union overwhelmingly backed industrial action in a ballot.Eighty-eight per cent voted to strike, with  per cent backing action short of a strike. Turnout was  per cent.However, the union and representatives of Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdare to hold talks ndash scheduled for Friday ndash in a bid to resolve the dispute. Hial is owned by the Scottish Government.If there is no resolution then action could be taken at seven airports, including Wick John OGroats, in April and continue through the summer. Others that would be affected are Inverness, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway, Benbecula and Dundee.Prospect negotiations officer David Avery said air traffic controllers working for Hial will be taking strike action on April , although action short of a strike will start on April  and continue until August . That could include working to rosters, an overtime ban and the withdrawal of goodwill.However, the union wants to ensure there is cover for emergency incidents during any strike.Mr Avery also pointed out that Prospect members agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish Easter school holidays."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays," he said."I urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice."Air traffic controllers do not want to have to take this action but ministersrsquo refusal to engage with the issue of pay has left them with no choice. Prospect remains ready to negotiate at any point to avoid this action but ministers must come back to the table with a new, meaningful offer."Hial managing director Inglis Lyon said industrial action is likely to have "a signicant impact on passengers and the communities in the Highlands and Islands".He said: "The Prospect union has sought a double-digit pay award. As a government-sponsored agency, Hial must follow the Scottish Government pay policy. We cannot implement pay awards more than that directed by government."Mr Lyon explained that a three per cent increase was offered to all staff at the end of September. Air traffic controllers rejected the offer and want a rise thought to be around  per cent."We are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for air traffic control staff that would further bolster an attractive remuneration package that already includes excellent pension benefits and holiday entitlements," he added.Highlands and Islands MSP John Finnie, who is the Scottish Greens transport spokesman, said: "The Scottish ministers own HIAL and have a responsibility to ensure this situation is resolved urgently with a fair settlement for staff."His Conservative colleague, Edward Mountain, said: "I am disappointed HIAL air traffic controllers are considering strike action regarding their pay claim."Airports in Inverness, Sumburgh, Kirkwall, Wick John OrsquoGroats, Stornoway, Benbecula and Dundee are vital not only for businesses in the Highlands and Islands but also for holidaymakers. I urge both sides to continue to negotiate to find a solution that will prevent strike action."Meanwhile, a scheme which subsidises air fares for people in remote parts of Scotland has been extended until the end of next year.The decision to extend the Air Discount Scheme until December , , was welcomed by local MSP Gail Ross yesterday. She pointed out that from April  the scheme will cover the whole of Caithness and more areas in Sutherland.She said: "The Air Discount Scheme is not only vital to communities in the far north, but also very popular."This is a great example of the Scottish Governmentrsquos commitment to our rural communities and to widening access for local residents, encourage more visitors and also ensure more students in eligible areas are able to sign up to the scheme."The discount scheme provides travellers with a discount of  per cent on core air fares.Students studying in the eligible areas, but whose main residence is where, will also now be included in the scheme.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Barn owl numbers recover
story: CAITHNESS is considered to have the most northerly population of barn owls in the world ndash and they have recovered well after severe winters took their toll on numbers eight or nine years ago, according to RSPB Scotland.Representatives of the nature conservation charity were saddened to discover recently that a fit and healthy barn owl had apparently been killed by a vehicle in the county, but on the whole the birds are said to be doing well.Barn owls originally evolved in warm, dry climates where food is in abundance all year round. It is therefore unsurprising that barn owls in the north of Scotland have a hard time during the winter months, with peak mortality rates being between December and March due to starvation.As temperatures start to drop in winter, small mammals become less active, meaning a lot less food is available for barn owls, and they need to work extra-hard to find it. This often results in the owls being forced to feed during daylight, even though they are naturally nocturnal hunters.This lack of food is particularly dangerous for barn owls as they are poorly insulated and need more food in winter to provide them with enough energy to stay warm.The Barn Owl Trust estimates that between  and  barn owls are killed each year on UK roads.RSPB Scotland site manager Dave Jones recently sent a deceased barn owl to the Scottish Agricultural College in Thurso for autopsy, when some concerned neighbours reported it after finding it at the roadside.The results of the autopsy showed that the bird was fit and healthy, "in good shape and hunting successfully", and that the death followed trauma to its wing and abdomen ndash suggesting that the bird died as a result of being hit by a vehicle.Dave said: "It is extremely sad to discover that a fit and healthy birds le ended in this way. The barn owls in Caithness really are at the edge of their natural comfort zone and are particularly vulnerable in winter, so it isnt an unusual result, unfortunately. Its not all doom and gloom, though. Although we still find some casualties in this way, our population of barn owls in Caithness has recovered from the particularly poor winters of   and  , and they are considered to be the most northerly population of barn owls in the world."While we cant control the weather, there are some things we can do to help. If putting up a nest box, please make sure it isnt placed close to any busy roads. If you see a road casualty and it is safe to do so, please stop and report the find to your local wildle officer and to the Barn Owl Trust. This is helpful in identying accident black spots and monitoring for environmental hazards and poisons, and potential wildle crime."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Businesses in Thurso urged to work together to help develop tourism
story: BUSINESSES must work together to help develop tourism in Thurso.That was the key message from a meeting attended by more than  people representing ious aspects of the industry, including accommodation, tours, transport and town centre shops.They met on Friday to discuss the Destination Thurso project which is being run by Thurso Community Development Trust .Last year, it conducted a community consultation which found development of tourism in the town was a priority need.The trust has since secured funding from Highland Leader and the Caithness and North Sutherland Fund to run its Destination Thurso project which employs a tourism development officer to oversee a project that will create a website, associated social media, workshops and a tourism development plan.Helen Allan, vice-chairperson of the trust, said: ldquoWe had a strong iety of dferent tourism businesses and organisations attending the meeting.ldquoI think sometimes it might be thought that tourism is only reliant on accommodation providers but that isnrsquot strictly true ndash visitors come into contact with a wide iety of services when coming to our town, from taxi drivers to town centre shops. We all have a role to play in promoting Thurso to a visitor, right down to the community who may be approached on the street by a visitor looking for directions.Fiona Carlisle, of Messy Nessy Play Centre, said: ldquoIt was brilliant to see so many local businesses coming together and being positive while looking at dferent ways to support and engage with each other regarding tourism.A Tourism Working Group for Thurso has been formed to look at ious issues, while workshops are to be run to help local people provide tourist information to visitors.Trust project officer Joan Lawrie said: ldquoThe workshops will be open to businesses for their staff and the wider public should they have an interest.ldquoWork is ongoing on the Destination Thurso website which is due to launch prior to the start of the summer season at the end of April.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Scottish Government urged to help secure future of Caithness Horizons
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to "play its part in securing a future for Caithness Horizons".It was made by local MP Jamie Stone in a letter to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and comes after talks between representatives of the museum and gallery and Highland Council.Horizons chairman Craig Brown said: "The meeting was positive in discussing possible options for long-term financial stability to allow Caithness Horizons to reopen. Further meetings are scheduled over the coming weeks."Regarding widespread concern about the future of the museum collection, Mr Brown said it "remains complete and in the same safe condition while the next steps are discussed" with the local authority.Mr Stone, the MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, described Horizons ndash which closed unexpectedly last week ndash as part of "a string of pearls" to entice visitors to the area, the others being the Castle of Mey and Dunrobin Castle.He urged the First Minister to help identy a way "to keep this vital facility open".Mr Stone said: "I was appalled to hear of this closure ndash not least because it doesnrsquot seem that long since it was first opened. Caithness Horizons has been a great success in interpreting the geology, wildle and history of the far north for local people and visitors alike. It is up to date, visually striking, full of information and everyone who has been has come away much enthused."The closure of Caithness Horizons is precisely what we cannot allow to happen and it is for this reason that the Scottish Government should play its part in securing a future for the facility."Councillor Struan Mackie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, is concerned about public statements on dispersing the collection and says that is "contrary to the founding principles of Horizons".He said any part of the permanent collection not on loan "must remain in Caithness, regardless of the future of the Horizons facility. And in the event of closure the permanent collection would revert to the Highland Council."Councillor Mackie says the local authority should explore alternative operating models and wants "a cast iron commitment to ensure our countys heritage stays in Caithness for future generations."Ian Leith, chairman of the Wick Society, which runs Wick Heritage Museum in the townrsquos Bank Row, described the closure of Caithness Horizons as "a great loss"."From a heritage point of view it is certainly important, particularly its collection which should not be broken up and dispersed," he said.Mr Leith emphasised that the heritage groups in Caithness are not in competition "but telling parts of the same story". He said: Caithness Horizons had its part to play. Now its gone it is a great loss, but hopefully it can be retrieved."He said the Thurso museum and gallery had "very dedicated and very experienced staff".Mr Leith added: "It is too important to lose, particularly its heritage collection which has a national signicance. If it was broken up it would dilute the story. Whatever the future holds, the collection must be retained."Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Slow progress on old church
story: A COUPLE who want to transform a derelict church in Castletown into their home say their plans are "progressing slowly".Angus Cowap and Dr Heather Davis purchased the th century church near the village primary school from Highland Council a year ago and have been "clearing a lot of rubbish" from the site but are now preparing for the next stage of the project.Mr Cowap said numerous consultations, studies and negotiations have been carried out and the proposals are beginning to take shape.The couple, who moved to the village three years ago, plan to replace the ruined roof and put some solar  on the south face of the building, re-glaze the windows and construct a double garage and a conservatory sun room."Internally, we will strip out the ruined fabric and make a simple open-plan living space," Mr Cowap said, stressing it will be a long-term project.He and Dr Davis moved north when she joined a medical practice in Thurso.They have spent some time clearing trees which were in danger of undermining the structure and have been shting rubbish, including rusty old cars and vehicle parts, from around the site.The church is believed to date back to  and was used by the RAF as a mess hall in World War II. It was later the site for residential caravans.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Urgent action needed after twins are born 52 miles apart
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to act on maternity provision in Caithness after a mother gave birth to twins at hospitals  miles apart.Local MP Jamie Stone described what happened as "a fiasco" and "shameful" and said it was time First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and her cabinet took action to deal with the situation.Highlands and Islands MSP Rhoda Grant raised the matter in the Scottish Parliament, while Caithness Health Action Teamsaid the case highlighted the maternity problems in the far north.Mr Stone, the Liberal Democrat MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, said: "No woman should have to face this when giving birth. It is shameful that it has taken a fiasco like this for the Scottish Government to sit up and take notice."Thankfully, the mother and both babies are healthy and we must thank the local NHS staff for their excellent work."However, this is a situation that neither the mother nor the staff should have been put in and we desperately need action from the Scottish Government."Geography and distance should not be something expectant mothers have to deal with and the government must accept that no-one should lack access to health services simply because of where they live."He spoke out after the womans ordeal was made public. She went to Caithness General Hospital in Wick in November after her waters broke when she was  weeks pregnant.It was decided she should go by ambulance to Raigmore in Inverness, over  miles away, to have her babies.But as she was near Golspie, her contractions became stronger and she was taken to the local community hospital, the Lawson Memorial, where she gave birth to a boy.A helicopter was then to take the woman to the Highland capital but was unable to land due to frost on its propellers so she made the rest of the journey by ambulance and gave birth to the second twin.Labours Rhoda Grant raised the case in parliament and claimed the air ambulance should have been called when the woman went into labour.She asked: "It begs the question why was the air ambulance or emergency retrieval team not tasked initially to airlt the mum from Caithness "Will the First Minister investigate this and will she make sure that the air ambulance treats situations like this as a priority "Nicola Sturgeon promised to investigate and asked Scotlands health secretary, Jeane Freeman, to look into it.Bill Fernie, the chairman of Chat, said the case highlighted the groups concerns about mothers having to travel to Inverness to give birth."Fortunately, we have not had a tragedy yet and hopefully we never will ndash but this underlines the fears we have had since the changes were made to the local maternity unit. There has been no risk assessment for the people who have to travel to Raigmore to have their babies."There has never been a problem with care at Caithness General or Raigmore, but mothers here should get the same kind of access to treatment as they get in the cities and we used to have here. Why in an emergency cant the experts be on call to come to Wick rather than the other way round "I hope this Scottish Government investigation comes up with some solutions to this whole problem."NHS Highland said an internal review will be carried out to consider the specic circumstances of this case.Saturday  Mar  : AM

title: Wetherspoon pub in Wick put up for sale
story: THE Wetherspoon pub in Wick and its  staff face an uncertain future after the business was put up for sale.The company said the decision was a commercial one but stressed the pub - named after the th century Watten inventor Alexander Bain - will remian open until a buyer is found.Far north SNP MSP, Gail Ross, described the announcement as "a big shock" but took some comfort from the fact it may not close.For full story see todays GroatSaturday  Mar  : AM

title: air traffic controllers set date for strike action
story: Air traffic controllers at Kirkwall Airport will go on strike on Friday, April , in relation to their   pay offer.Prospect air traffic controllers will take action at seven airports: Dundee, Inverness, Wick, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway and Benbecula.Action short of a strike will commence on Monday, April  and continue throughout the summer to Saturday, August .This will include instruction to work to rosters refusal of non-medical extensions an overtime ban and withdrawal of good will.Prospect will also seek to agree a protocol with HIAL to ensure cover for emergency incidents during the period of the strike.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: “Prospect members have agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish school holidays have concluded. Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays.“I urge HIAL and Scottish Ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: government has a responsibility to resolve air traffic controllers situation says finnie
story: Highlands and Islands Scottish Green Party MSP John Finnie has said the Scottish Government and Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd have a responsibility to resolve the dispute with air traffic controllers and has offered his support to the Prospect union and its members.The Scottish Green MSP, who is his party#s spokesperson on transport, said: “The Scottish ministers own HIAL and have a responsibility to ensure this situation is resolved urgently, with a fair settlement for staff. It’s perhaps no surprise that the transport secretary refused to say he had confidence in HIAL’s management the last time I asked him. I continue to offer solidarity and support to Prospect and its members.”The Prospect union said that, following a ballot of air traffic controllers who are members of the union,  per cent had voted for strike action, with  per cent backing action short of a strike.The dispute has come about after the pay rise was sought by the controllers, as they said they were being paid half as much as their counterparts in other areas. However, HIAL and the Scottish Government turned down the request denying this was the case.Prospect has said action is likely to start in April.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur presses government on fair ferry funding
story: Responding to news that government funding for Orkney’s leline ferry services has decreased by £, since last year — leaving a shortfall of £,, — Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has again pressed the Scottish Government to honour its commitments to fair ferry funding.Mr McArthur is concerned that Orkney Islands Council will be forced to implement a three per cent rise in fairs. He questioned Minister for Public Finance, Kate Forbes MSP, in the Scottish Parliament earlier this afternoon, Wednesday, asking how this shortfall squares with the government’s commitment to the principle of fair funding for our leline internal ferry services.According to the Orkney MSP, the minister responded by saying that the government recognise the challenges in running these ferry services and that they have been clear in their budget that adequate funding is to be delivered.Commenting after the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “We now know that the Scottish Government has cut funding for Orkney’s internal ferry services by £, compared to last year.  This has left a £.m shortfall in the Council’s budget for delivering these leline services.#It is baffling how Ministers think this approach is consistent with their commitment to the principle of fair ferry funding.  It certainly flies in the face of the will of parliament, which voted for the government to deliver on its earlier promises.“Meantime, the island communities that rely on these leline services are left picking up the tab, including a three per cent increase in fares this year.  Ministers may ‘recognise’ the challenges of running these services, but they also must recognise their obligations genuinely to provide adequate funding.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
